revision.text:
'''ABKO Properties''' was a [[joint venture]] between [[Wichita, Kansas]] [[real estate]] entrepreneur George Ablah and Wichita-based [[Koch Industries]] formed specifically to purchase Chrysler Realty Corporation in the late 1970s from a hard-pressed [[Lee Iacocca]]. Koch Industries is ranked 2 among the Forbes list of largest private companies. Chrysler Realty Corporation purchases, leases or options dealership facilities and then leases or subleases these facilities to Chrysler dealers. The name ABKO was derived from the first two letters of Ablah’s name and the first two letters of Charles Koch’s name, who is head of Koch Industries. At the time ABKO was formed, Chrysler was on the verge of bankruptcy.
==History==
ABKO purchased around 840 Chrysler [[Car dealerships in the USA|automotive dealership]] sites around the country controlled by Iacocca in 1979 for slightly over $100 million in cash. Not all the sites were owned by Chrysler Realty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chrysler's Realty Sale May Be Overly Touted|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1979/09/16/chryslers-realty-sale-may-be-overly-touted/9ca2d3dc-7163-42ae-844c-7a0f35ee3037/|website=The Washington Post|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref>
Under the leadership of Ablah and his team, Chrysler Realty president Ed Homer (for a brief time), executive vice president Corliss (Corky) Nelson of Koch,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10D10FF3B5C0C728CDDAB0894DA484D81|title=EXECUTIVES|date=1982-02-01|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2008-06-09}}</ref> acquisition/disposition specialists Wayne Delfino and Frank Mills, and attorney John Schippel, among others, ABKO set forth a strategy to diversify Chrysler Realty Corporation by way of liquidating non-performing Chrysler dealership properties by tax-free exchange and sale.
In 1983, Iacocca, assisted by a government bailout he organized, repurchased 446 of the dealerships in a measure aimed at strengthening the Chrysler dealer network. ABKO dissolved shortly thereafter.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{Koch Industries}}

{{Infobox company | name = ARIAD Pharmaceuticals, Inc. | logo = ARIAD logo.png | logo_size = 151px | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{NASDAQ was|ARIA}} | fate = Merged with [[Takeda Pharmaceuticals]] | foundation = 1991 | defunct = 2017 | location = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge, MA]], [[United States]] | key_people = '''[[Harvey Berger]]''',
Founder, chairman, and CEO Emeritus
'''Alex Denner''',
Chairman of the Board
'''Timothy P. Clackson''',
President of Research and Development and Chief Scientific Officer
'''Ed Fitzgerald''', (Former CFO)
'''Marty Duvall''', (Former CCO) | industry = [[Pharmaceutical company|Pharmaceuticals]], [[biotechnology]] | products = [[Ponatinib]] (FDA approved, trade name Iclusig)
[[Ridaforolimus]] (FDA approved)
[[Brigatinib]] (FDA approved)
Rimiducid (Under development)
AP32788 (Under development) | revenue = [[United States Dollar|US$]]118.8M (''FY 2015''){{cite web|title=ARIAD PHARMACEUTICALS INC (ARIA) SEC Filing 10-K Annual report|url=https://www.last10k.com/sec-filings/aria#toc19643_11|website=Last10K.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}} | operating_income = [[United States Dollar|US$]](217.27M) (''FY 2015'') | net_income = [[United States Dollar|US$]](231.16M) (''FY 2015'') | assets = [[United States Dollar|US$]]546.69M (''FY 2015'') | num_employees = 380 (2016){{cite web|last1=Seiffert|first1=Don|title=Ariad to lay off 90 people across the company in cost-cutting measure|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/bioflash/2016/03/ariad-to-lay-off-90-people-across-the-company-in.html|website=Boston Business Journal|accessdate=9 January 2018}} | homepage = [http://www.ariad.com/ www.ariad.com] }} '''ARIAD Pharmaceuticals, Inc.''' was an American [[oncology]] company, now part of Takeda Oncology, which was founded in 1991 by [[Harvey Berger|Harvey J. Berger, M.D.]] and headquartered in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. ARIAD engaged in the discovery, development, and commercialization of medicines for cancer patients. ARIAD’s most prominent drug discoveries include Iclusig, designed for patients with all forms of Philadelphia chromosome-positive [Ph+] [[Chronic myelogenous leukemia|chronic myeloid leukemia]] (CML) or Ph+ [[acute lymphoblastic leukemia]] (ALL) who are resistant to or unable to tolerate other [[tyrosine kinase]] inhibitors, and [[brigatinib]], a [[lung cancer]] drug which has completed its registration trial in ALK fusion driven non-small cell lung cancer as of June 2016 and was approved in the U.S. in April 2017. In January 2017, [[Takeda Pharmaceutical Company|Takeda]] announced it would acquire ARIAD for $5.2 billion, expanding the company's oncology and hematology business. On February 16, 2017, Takeda Pharmaceuticals, Ltd. announced it had completed its acquisition of ARIAD and incorporated ARIAD into Takeda Oncology.http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/takeda-to-acquire-ariad-pharmaceuticals-for-52b/81253671 ==Company history== ARIAD Pharmaceuticals, Inc. was founded in 1991 in Cambridge, Massachusetts by Harvey J. Berger, M.D. ARIAD raised $46 million as its initial financing in 1992, making it the single highest round of funding in the biotechnology industry at that time.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/03/27/business/company-news-ariad-raises-46-million-in-placement.html|title=COMPANY NEWS; Ariad Raises $46 Million In Placement|last=Pollack|first=Rew|date=1992-03-27|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ARIAD filed for an initial public offering through NASDAQ in 1994.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/16/business/equity-issues-this-week.html|title=Equity Issues This Week|date=1994-05-16|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ARIAD established its European headquarters in [[Lausanne|Lausanne, Switzerland]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/bioflash/2016/05/ariad-sells-european-operations-for-140m-upfront.html|title=Ariad sells European operations for $140M upfront plus royalties|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-12}} The company sells and markets its initial drug, Iclusig, through specialty pharmacies and specialty distributors in the United States. In 2016, ARIAD sold its European business and the distribution of Iclusig to Incyte Corp and now receives royalties and other payments from Incyte based on Iclusig sales in the EU. ARIAD also developed two small-molecule drugs, ridaforolimus and rimiducid, and licensed them to companies with complementary technologies.{{Cite news|url=https://www.streetinsider.com/Corporate+News/ARIAD+Pharma+(ARIA)+Will+Update+on+Key+Initiatives+for+FY15;+Offers+Prelim.+FY14+Numbers/10159308.html|title=ARIAD Pharma (ARIA) Will Update on Key Initiatives for FY15; Offers Prelim. FY14 Numbers|work=StreetInsider.com|access-date=2017-12-12}} In July 2015, the company announced it was due to receive up to $200 million through a [[royalty financing]] deal with [[PDL BioPharma]]. ARIAD is obligated to repay the $200 mm and a predefined interest, with the note being guaranteed by future sales of [[ponatinib]]{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/ariad-to-receive-up-to-200m-in-royalty-deal/81251568/|title=Ariad to Receive Up-to $200M in Royalty Deal - GEN Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News - Biotech from Bench to Business - GEN|publisher=}} and in some cases, brigatinib.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bioworld.com/content/ariad-pharmaceuticals-strikes-synthetic-royalty-deal-pdl-back-cancer-programs|title=Ariad Pharmaceuticals strikes synthetic royalty deal with PDL to back cancer programs|website=BioWorld|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}} On February 21, 2014 ARIAD Pharmaceuticals announced the appointment of Sarissa Capital's Alexander J. Denner, Ph.D. to a two-year term on the company's Board of Directors and became ARIAD's second-largest shareholder. In 2016, ARIAD announced that Denner had become the chairman of the board{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160110005030/en/ARIAD-Announces-Election-Alex-Denner-Chairman-Board|title=ARIAD Announces Election of Alex Denner as Chairman of the Board of Directors|publisher=Business Wire}} and the company announced the termination of its shareholder's rights plan.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160111005320/en/ARIAD-Announces-Termination-Shareholder-Rights-Plan|title=ARIAD Announces Termination of Shareholder Rights Plan -|publisher=Business Wire}} In 2016, the company was ranked #3 on the [[Deloitte Fast 500#Fast 500 North America|Deloitte Fast 500 North America]] list.{{cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/technology-media-and-telecommunications/articles/fast500-winners.html?nc=1|title=2016 Winners by rank|publisher=[[Deloitte]]|accessdate=15 September 2017}} Berger retired as chairman and CEO of ARIAD in December 2015 and became Founder, chairman and CEO Emeritus as of January 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2017/01/09/takeda-deal-results-in-a-huge-windfall-for-former.html|title=Takeda deal results in a huge windfall for former Ariad CEO Harvey Berger|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-12}}{{Cite web|url=https://medcitynews.com/2017/05/biotech-figure-henri-termeer-dies-at-71/|title=Larger-than-life biotech figure Henri Termeer dies at 71 - MedCity News|website=medcitynews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-12}} ==Products== ===FDA-approved products=== ====Ponatinib (Iclusig) ==== ARIAD developed Ponatinib (Iclusig), a tyrosine kinase inhibitor for the treatment of adult patients with Philadelphia chromosome-positive [Ph+] [[Chronic myelogenous leukemia|chronic myeloid leukemia]] (CML), and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.{{Cite news|url=https://www.investopedia.com/news/ariads-iclusig-gets-fda-ok-and-label-update-aria/|title=Ariad Leukemia Drug Gets Full US Approval (ARIA)|last=Seth|first=Shobhit|date=2016-11-30|work=Investopedia|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US}} On December 14, 2012 the [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] approved ARIAD's leukemia drug Ponatinib for patients with all forms of Ph+ CML or Ph+ [[acute lymphoblastic leukemia]] (ALL) who are resistant to or unable to tolerate other [[tyrosine kinase]] inhibitors.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pmlive.com/pharma_thought_leadership/interview_harvey_berger_and_timothy_clackson,_ariad_509032|title=Interview: Harvey Berger and Timothy Clackson, Ariad|date=2013-10-14|website=www.pmlive.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}} The drug was temporarily withdrawn from the U.S. market in November 2013{{Cite news|url=https://medicalletter.wordpress.com/2013/11/21/ponatinib-withdrawn-a-pharmaceutical-tragedy/|title=Ponatinib Withdrawn: A Pharmaceutical Tragedy|last=|first=|date=2013-11-21|work=More@MedLetter|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} because of the risk of [[blood clot]]s and severe narrowing of blood vessels.{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DrugSafety/ucm373040.htm|title=Drug Safety and Availability - FDA Drug Safety Communication: FDA asks manufacturer of the leukemia drug Iclusig (ponatinib) to suspend marketing and sales|publisher=Center for Drug Evaluation and Research}} Ponatinib was returned to the market in the U.S. on December 20, 2013 with revised prescribing information, new warnings and a REMS. ARIAD had set up an emergency-access program for Ponatinib, which provided drugs to patients in need during this six-week period.{{Cite web|url=https://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/ariad-s-iclusig-returns-to-u-s-commercial-market/81249391|title=Ariad's Iclusig Returns to U.S. Commercial Market {{!}} GEN|website=GEN|access-date=2017-12-12}} Ponatinib remained on the market in all European countries and was subsequently approved in Japan. ====Brigatinib (Alunbrig) ==== ARIAD’s product pipeline includes [[brigatinib]], an inhibitor of [[anaplastic lymphoma kinase]] [ALK] for treating ALK+ non-small cell lung cancer. This drug reported results of its registration trial at ASCO, June 6, 2016, with encouraging results, leading to approval in the U.S. in April 2017.{{cite web|url=http://phx.corporate-ir.net/External.File?item=UGFyZW50SUQ9MzQxMDk4fENoaWxkSUQ9LTF8VHlwZT0z&t=1&cb=636008135469722045|title=Brigatinib in Patients With Crizotinib-Refractory ALK+ Non–Small Cell Lung Cancer: First Report of Efficacy and Safety From a Pivotal Randomized Phase 2 Trial (ALTA)|author=Dong-Wan Kim, et al.|date=June 2016|publisher=The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cancer.gov/news-events/cancer-currents-blog/2017/brigatinib-fda-lung-cancer|title=Brigatinib Approved by FDA for Lung Cancer|website=National Cancer Institute|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}} Brigatinib was designated a Breakthrough Medicine by the FDA.{{Cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/drugs/informationondrugs/approveddrugs/ucm555841.htm|title=Approved Drugs - Brigatinib|last=Research|first=Center for Drug Evaluation and|website=www.fda.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}} ====Ridaforolimus (formerly Deforolimus, partnered with Medinol) ==== [[Ridaforolimus]] is an [[mTOR inhibitor]] being developed by Medinol Ltd for use in drug-eluting stents for patients with coronary artery disease.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/bioflash/2014/01/ariad-could-enter-medical-device.html|title=Ariad could enter medical device market with trial drug-eluting stent|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-12}} Medinol has completed two registrational trials in patients with coronary artery disease, which met its primary and secondary endpoints.{{Cite news|url=https://www.medgadget.com/2017/10/elunir-drug-eluting-stent-from-medinol-wins-european-clearance.html|title=EluNIR Drug-Eluting Coronary Stent from Medinol Wins European Clearance {{!}}|date=2017-10-30|work=Medgadget|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US}} In October 2017, Medinol’s EluNIR drug eluting stent, coated with ridaforolimus, received CE Mark in Europe. In November 2017, it was approved for marketing in the U.S. by the FDA.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tctmd.com/news/fda-approves-elunir-drug-eluting-stent|title=FDA Approves EluNIR Drug-Eluting Stent|website=TCTMD.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}} === Products under development === Various company-sponsored and investigator-sponsored trials are ongoing in several indications, including first line and second line CML, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (BCR-ABL), acute myeloid leukemia (FLT3 inhibitor), non-small cell lung cancer (RET, FGFR), advanced biliary cancer with [[FGFR2]] fusions and other cancers with activating mutations involving the following genes: [[FGFR1]], FGFR2, [[FGFR3]], [[FGFR4]], [[RET proto-oncogene|RET]], and [[KIT (gene)|KIT]].{{cite web|url=https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=ponatinib&Search=Search|title=Search of: ponatinib - List Results|publisher=ClinicalTrials.gov}}{{better source|date=October 2016}} ==== Rimiducid ==== Rimiducid is an investigational chemical dimerizer being developed by partner, Bellicum Pharmaceuticals and is in Phase 3 clinical trials.{{Cite news|url=https://immuno-oncologynews.com/2016/08/09/bellicum-announces-bpx-501-european-regulatory-updates/|title=Promising Orphan Drugs to Help Pediatric Transplant Patients|date=2016-08-09|work=Immuno-Oncology News|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.fool.com/investing/2017/09/28/better-buy-bellicum-pharmaceuticals-inc-vs-bluebir.aspx|title=Better Buy: Bellicum Pharmaceuticals, Inc. vs. bluebird bio|last=Orelli|first=Brian|work=The Motley Fool|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en}} ==== AP32788 ==== AP32788 is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor of solid tumors with EGFR and HER2 activating mutation and began Phase 1/2 testing in the second quarter of 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.ariad.com/research-development/ap32788/|title=AP32788 is ARIAD's most recent, internally-discovered drug candidate|publisher=Ariad Pharmaceuticals}} ==See also== {{Portal|Companies}} *[[Merck & Co.|Merck]] *[[Bristol-Myers Squibb]] *[[Pfizer]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ariad.com/ Official ARIAD site] * [https://www.takeda.com/ Official Takeda site] * [http://medinol.com/ Official Medinol site] {{Pharmaceutical companies of the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ariad Pharmaceuticals}} [[Category:Companies formerly listed on NASDAQ]] [[Category:Merck]] [[Category:Defunct pharmaceutical companies of the United States]] [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies established in 1991]] [[Category:Companies based in Cambridge, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies of the United States]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies established in 1991]]

revision.text:
'''Albert A. Hakim''' (1936–April 25, 2003)<ref name=nytimesobit>{{cite news|title=Albert Hakim, Figure in Iran-Contra Affair, Dies at 66|work=New York Times|date=May 1, 2003|accessdate=December 28, 2009|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/01/us/albert-hakim-figure-in-iran-contra-affair-dies-at-66.html?pagewanted=1 | first=Douglas | last=Martin}}</ref><ref name="Los Angeles Times; April 30, 2003">{{cite news |last=Oliver |first=Myrna |date=April 30, 2003 |title=Albert Hakim, 66; Key Figure in Reagan Era's Iran-Contra Scandal |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/apr/30/local/me-hakim30 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |location=Los Angeles |access-date=May 4, 2015}}</ref> was an Iranian-American businessman and a figure in the [[Iran-Contra affair]].<ref name=nytimesobit/><ref name=timemagobit>{{cite news|title=Milestones May 12, 2003|work=Time Magazine|date=May 12, 2003|accessdate=December 28, 2009|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1004835,00.html | first1=Melissa | last1=August | first2=Harriet | last2=Barovick | first3=Elizabeth L. | last3=Bland | first4=Unmesh | last4=Kher | first5=Lisa | last5=McLaughlin | first6=Sora | last6=Song}}</ref>
Born in [[Iran]],<ref name=nytimesobit/> Hakim attended [[California Polytechnic State University|California Polytechnic Institute]] for 3 years, beginning in 1955.<ref name=nytimesobit/> Back in Iran, he established an export business specializing in advanced technologies, and in avoiding export restrictions related to them.<ref name=nytimesobit/> He also participated in [[Project Dark Gene|Project Ibex]] for the [[CIA]].<ref name=CrimesOfAPresident>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-CwkeJq6ozMC&lpg=PA77&ots=pqpE-Z255G&dq=richard%20secord%20ibex&pg=PA78#v=onepage&q=richard%20secord%20ibex&f=false |title=Crimes Of A President: ew Revelations on the Conspiracy and Cover Up...|author=Joel Bainerman}}</ref>
Hakim was ''[[persona non grata]]'' in Iran.<ref name="Iran/Contra report">{{cite book |author=U.S. Senate Select Committee on Secret Military Assistance to Iran and the Nicaraguan Opposition, U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee to Investigate Covert Arms Transactions with Iran |author-link=Congressional committees investigating the Iran–Contra Affair |title=Report of the Congressional Committees Investigating the Iran/Contra Affair With Supplemental, Minority, and Additional Views |url=https://archive.org/details/reportofcongress87unit |date=1987 |publisher=United States Government Printing Office |location=Washington, D.C. |page=251 |id=S. Rept. No. 100-216, H. Rept. No. 100-433 |oclc=16998535 |ref={{harvid|Report of the Congressional Committees Investigating the Iran/Contra Affair|1993}}}}</ref>
Hakim was credited with negotiating a 9-point plan known as the 'Hakim Accords',<ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1346&dat=19870606&id=6IkwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k_sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6685,1684320</ref> in which he negotiated the release of David P. Jacobsen, an American hostage held by the Islamic Republic of Iran from the [[Iran Hostage Crisis]]. Later, during Hakim's trial for his role in the Iran-Contra affair, Jacobsen wrote a letter in Hakim's defense in which he stated: "I would be in my fifth year of captivity had it not been for his [Hakim's] extraordinary efforts in negotiating with the Iranian representatives. Other American negotiators had given up, but Mr. Hakim continued."<ref>http://english.ohmynews.com/articleview/article_view.asp?menu=c10400&no=381164&rel_no=1</ref>
Hakim moved to California in the early 1980s, and in 1983 established [[Stanford Technology Trading Group International]] (STTGI) with Major General [[Richard Secord|Richard V. Secord]], Retired. STTGI subsequently became involved in illegal covert operations to supply the [[Nicaragua]]n [[contras]], as part of the Iran-Contra affair.<ref name=nytimesobit/><ref>Dan Morain, ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 12 February 1987, [http://articles.latimes.com/1987-02-12/news/mn-2874_1_arms-sales CIA Contacted by Arms Middleman in 1983, Source Says]</ref> For his part in the matter, Hakim was charged with five felonies which were dismissed and subsequently pleaded guilty in a [[plea bargain]] to a misdemeanor, and was sentenced to probation and a fine of $5000.<ref name=nytimesobit/><ref>http://www.brown.edu/Research/Understanding_the_Iran_Contra_Affair/profile-hakim.php</ref>
Hakim died of a [[heart attack]] in [[Inchon, South Korea]], where he had moved to be near his wife's parents.<ref name=nytimesobit/><ref name=timemagobit/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hakim, Albert}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2003 deaths]] [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:Iran–Contra affair]]

revision.text:
The '''Anheuser family''' is a family from the [[Nahe (wine region)|Nahe]] in the [[Rhineland-Palatinate]]. The American [[brewery]] family of [[Anheuser-Busch]] fame are descendants of [[Eberhard Anheuser]] who was born in [[Bad Kreuznach]]. The Anheuser family has been producing [[German wine]] in the Nahe since the 17th century and has continued producing wine for 13 [[generation]]s under the name of Weingut Paul Anheuser.<ref name="Diel pg 263">A. Diel & J. Payne ''"German Wine Guide" pg 263 Abbeville Press Publishers 1999 {{ISBN|0-7892-0577-7}} </ref>
== History == The earliest record of [[winemaking]] by the Anheusers dates to 1627 with an Anheuser operating a winery in Bad Kreuznach.<ref name="Diel pg 263"/> In 1842, Eberhard Anheuser immigrated to [[St. Louis, Missouri]] while his nephew Rudolf Anheuser began purchasing more vineyards in the [[Nahe (wine region)|Nahe]] valley around the towns of [[Altenbamberg]], [[Monzingen]], [[Niederhausen]], [[Norheim]], [[Schloßböckelheim]] and [[Roxheim]].<ref name="Anheuser">Paul Anheuser ''"[http://www.anheuser.de/us/tradition.htm Family history] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807161157/http://www.anheuser.de/us/tradition.htm |date=August 7, 2007 }}"''</ref> In 1861, Eberhard Anheuser would marry both of his daughters to the sons of a German wine merchant from [[Mainz]] and open a brewery with one of his sons-in-law, [[Adolphus Busch]].<ref> Time Magazine ''"[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,807368-6,00.html The Baron of Beer]"'' pg 6 , July 11th 1955 </ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * Paul Anheuser [http://www.anheuser.de Official Site] * Anheuser-Busch [http://www.anheuser-busch.com/History.html History]
[[Category:Business families of the United States]] [[Category:German wine]] [[Category:Busch family| ]] [[Category:People from Bad Kreuznach]] [[Category:People from St. Louis]]

{{Orphan|date=November 2017}} [[File:Antonio z atienza,jr.jpg|thumb|right|275px|Antonio Z. Atienza Jr., Filipino jeweler.]] '''Antonio Z. Atienza Jr.''' (born August 30, 1959) is a [[Philippines|Filipino]] [[jeweler]]. As a manufacturer, exporter, and retailer of fine jewelry products, he is the owner of Goldenas Jewelry, Inc. He is a member of the Guild of Philippine Jewelers, Inc. The Guild's mission as a national organization is to promote the transformation and growth of the Philippine jewelry industry.<ref>[http://www.guildofphilippinejewellersinc.com/directory7.htm Guild of Philippine Jewellers, Inc.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928030440/http://www.guildofphilippinejewellersinc.com/directory7.htm |date=September 28, 2007 }}</ref>
Atienza, Jr.'s Goldenas metamorphosed from Boy Atienza Jewel Art, a jewelry contracting shop, which started in 1982. With 3 employees, it has now under its employ a total of 80 craftsmen and personnel. It now sells jewelry made of gold and set with diamonds, pearls, and other semi-precious stones.<ref>[http://www.goldenasjewelry.com/about_us.htm Website of Goldenas]</ref> Atienza, Jr.'s Goldenhills Jewelry showcases his Goldenas, Inc. since 1982. Goldenhills Jewelry opened its first store on June 30, 2004 at the 2nd Floor of The Jewellery, Greenhills Shopping Center, and at present, has a total of 6 branches.<ref>http://www.goldenhillsjewelry.com/</ref> ==Awards== In December 2006, “Pakpak”, a half-necklace representing the wings of an eagle, intricately crafted by Goldenas, Inc., won the top spot of the All Precious Metals Category of the Guild of Philippine Jewellers’ Jewelry Design Competition. It received another award for the interpretation of a capiz necklace entitled, “Sensuality”, a winning design in the Chic Category of the Philippine Design Competition sponsored by the Meycauayan Jewelry Association on November 17, 2006. The Bulacan Chamber of Commerce and Industry awarded Atienza Jr. as Most Outstanding Bulacan Businessman in the Jewelry Industry on December 1, 2006.
In November 2005, Goldenas garnered two awards during the Fifth Philippine Fine Jewelry Design Competition at the Metro Comedy Bar in Quezon City. The design competition is an annual event organized by the Meycauayan Jewelry Industry Association, Inc. (MJIAI) in partnership with the Product Development and Design Center of the Philippines (Design Center).
"Eternal Love" was the top placer for the Wedding Category. Marie Liza DJ Cayana, the designer, works for Goldenas Jewelry, sponsor of the prototype. Christina Maris J. Juan of the University of Santo Tomas submitted the winning design for the Chic category with her "Down to Earth" entry. The necklace, according to Christina, is something you can take from work to play. Goldenas Jewelry also created the prototype.<ref>[http://www2.mozcom.com/~pddcp/5th%20Jewlry%20Competition.htm 5th P.I. JDC] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927040932/http://www2.mozcom.com/~pddcp/5th%20Jewlry%20Competition.htm |date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref> Goldenas, as a Philexport member, joined the Buy Pinoy goes to San Francisco from November 15 to 20, 2005 at the Philippine Center, 447 Sutter St.<ref>[http://www.goldenasjewelry.com/index.htm Website of Goldenas]</ref><ref>[http://www.goldenasjewelry.com/news_events.htm Goldenas, Events]</ref><ref>[http://www.mapua.edu.ph/news/?newsid=216 Mapua Institute of Technology]</ref><ref>[http://www.philippinecentersf.com/news/buy_pinoy.htm Philippine Center, SF] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929060240/http://www.philippinecentersf.com/news/buy_pinoy.htm |date=September 29, 2007 }}</ref>
In 2012, Antonio Z. Atienza Jr. (1979 Accounting) was named one of the Outstanding Alumni - Diamond Awardees of the [[University of Santo Tomas College of Commerce and Business Administration]][http://commerce.ust.edu.ph/index.php/alumni-affairs/well-known-alumni/diamond-awardee-75th-years].
==Kidnap for ransom== On March 24, 1997, Atienza Jr. was [[kidnapping|abducted]] by five armed men at Dona Mercedes [[Subdivision (land)|subdivision]], [[Barangay]] Libis, Iba, [[Meycauayan]], [[Bulacan]]. After a series of [[negotiations]] between the armed men and his wife Consolacion A. Atienza, his mother Virginia Atienza and brother Alfredo Atienza, he was released at [[Pasig City]], [[Metro Manila]] on March 27, 1997 upon payment of P 2.2 million [[ransom]] and P 1.5 million after several days. Atienza Jr. sought the assistance of [[police]] operatives (who created a special [[task force]] under Joseph Cabato, Military Intelligence Group, under PTFIC). CIG [[Chief of police|Chief]] [[superintendent (police)|superintendent]] Efren Fernandez arrested 2 suspects (at the [[Meycauayan]] [[gas]] [[Filling station|station]]): Felipe Montaos and Eduardo Soriano who pointed to Gerardo Roperez [[Pseudonym|alias]] Boy Sabater, as mastermind. The other 3 suspects were later caught: Armando Pablo @ Mando, Rudy Depas @ Rudy Bigote and Pablo Anora. In July 1997 and March 2001, [[Criminal]] cases were filed with the [[Office]] of the [[Province|Provincial]] [[Prosecutor]] of [[Bulacan]], and the case was docketed as "''People versus Armando Pablo, Rudy Depas and Roperez, et al.''" for kidnapping with ransom and robbery in band. Meanwhile, Atienza Jr., his wife Connie and all their children [[human migration|migrated]] to [[Australia]] due to the [[Psychological trauma|trauma]]. The remaining 2 other suspects were later arrested. On April 19, 2007, the [[Philippine Court of Appeals]] rendered a Decision penned by Justices Mariflor Castillo, Rodrigo Cosico and Rosemarie Carandang, affirming with modification the September 3, 2003 judgment of the [[Malolos City, Bulacan]] Court. Felipe Montaos and Eduardo Soriano were released for lack of evidence while Gerardo Roperez was acquitted and ordered released. Accused Pablo, Depas and Anora were found guilty of the crimes of kidnapping with ransom and simple robbery and meted the capital punishment of Reclusion Perpetua or life imprisonment and indeterminate penalty of 6 months as minimum to maximum of six years, respectively. They were ordered to pay Atienza Jr. P 3.7 million as actual damages.<ref>Crim. Cases Nos. 840-M-97 & 907-M-2001, September 3, 2003 9 pages Decision by Judge Basilio Gabo, in People vs. Armando Pablo @ Mando, Rudy Depas @ Rudy Bigote and Pablo Anora & Gerardo Roperez, et al., Br. 11, RTC, Malolos, Bulacan</ref><ref>CA-G.R. CR – H.C. No. 00962 “PEOPLE OF THE PHILIPPINES VS. ARMANDO PABLO, RUDY DEPAS, PABLO ANORA AND GERARDO ROPEREZ - April 19, 2007, Court of Appeals, 25-pages Judgment penned by CA Justices Mariflor Castillo, Rodrigo Cosico and Rosemarie Carandang, AFFIRMING the lower Court’s Decision with MODIFICATION. CA Reporter,</ref>
Meanwhile, Atienza, Jr.'s vast [[jewelry]] (one of the biggest in the [[Philippines]]) business flourished at his office at Saluysoy, [[Meycauayan]], [[Bulacan]]. He returned to the Philippines in 2001 to testify in the case and brought home his family from [[Australia]] after 7 years.(3-25, 1997 issue of Tempo, front page and page 2, by Rolly Carandang).<ref>[http://www.tempo.com.ph Tempo.com.ph, Dragnet bags 2 pf 7 persons in Jeweler's kidnap]</ref> ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons Category}} * [http://www.goldenhillsjewelry.com/index.php Goldenhills Jewelry] * [http://www.meycauayanjewellers.com/ Meycauayan Jewelry Industry Association, Inc.] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130614201101/http://philippine-jewelers.com/ Confederation of Philippine Jewelers Inc. (CPJI)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081019125839/http://business.inquirer.net/money/features/view/20081017-166875/Jeweler-with-golden-touch-makes-waves Jeweler with golden touch makes waves] * [http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/586198/symbol-undying-love A symbol of undying love Antonio Atienza of Goldenhills Jewelry] * [http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/09/09/12/branded-arras-not-just-weddings Branded 'arras' not just for weddings - Goldenhills Jewelry] * [http://orangemagazinetv.com/2012/endless-treasures-some-things-really-do-last-forever/ Endless Treasures: Some Things Really Do Last Forever…] {{DEFAULTSORT:Atienza, Antonio Jr.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Filipino jewellers]] [[Category:Filipino silversmiths]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Santo Tomas alumni]]

{{Infobox software | name = Any.do | logo = Any.do logo.png | developer = | operating system = [[Android (operating system)|Android]]
[[iOS]]
[[Google Chrome App]]
[[Web browser]] [[Macintosh|Mac]] [[Amazon Alexa|Alexa]] [[Chrome app]] [[Apple Watch]] [[Wear OS]] | genre = [[Productivity]]
[[Task management]]
[[Calendar]] [[Google Assistant|Assistant]] [[Grocery list]] [[Reminders]] | license = [[Freemium]] | website = {{URL|www.any.do}} }} '''Any.do''' is a productivity app designed to help people get more done. Any.do launched its to-do list and task list app in November of 2011 on Android followed by complimentary apps for iOS and Chrome{{cite web|last=Pierce|first=David|title=Any.do task manager launches for iOS and Chrome, now syncs across platforms (hands-on)|url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/6/3/3059220/any-do-tasks-app-ios-chrome-hands-on|publisher=The Verge|date=June 3, 2012}} in 2012, as well as a web app and a premium subscription model in 2014 {{cite web|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0%2c2817%2c2458349%2c00.asp|title=Any.do To-Do App Now Available on the Web|date=May 22, 2014|publisher=[[PC Magazine]]}}. By November 2013, Any.do reached over 7M users,{{cite web|last=Vozza|first=Stephanie|title=5 Habits of Productivity App Super Users|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/229897|publisher=Entrepreneur|date=Nov 18, 2013}} over 10 million users in March 2014, and 15 million in November 2016. In November 2016, the company launched Any.do 4, that combined the a to do list, a calendar, and a part AI part human personal assistant that can complete users tasks in a single app.{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/next-evolution-productivity-omer-perchik?published=t|title=The Next Evolution of Productivity|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} In 2017, the company announced a partnership with Amazon Alexa and Slack. In 2018, the company launched a smart grocery list and shopping list feature as well as integration with Google Assistant and Siri. Any.do was co-founded by Omer Perchik, Itay Kahana, and Yoni Lindenfeld. It has offices in both [[Tel Aviv]] and [[San Francisco]]. == History == Prior to Any.do, co-founders ''Omer Perchik'', ''Itay Kahana'' and ''Yoni Lindenfeld'' launched a simpler version of the app on [[Android (operating system)|Android]] called Taskos.{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Tessa|title=I'm Omer Perchik, and This Is the Story Behind Any.do|url=http://lifehacker.com/im-omer-perchik-and-this-is-the-story-behind-any-do-1440128266|publisher=Lifehacker|date=Oct 10, 2013}} By 2010, Taskos had 1.3 million users and served as a test version for what would eventually become Any.do.{{cite web|last=Van Grove|first=Jennifer|title=Collaborative to-do app Any.do puts Reminders to shame|url=https://venturebeat.com/2011/11/10/any-do/|publisher=Venturebeat|date=Nov 10, 2011}} The company opened development offices in Tel Aviv, Israel and opened its business headquarters in San Francisco, California in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://allthingsd.com/20120604/well-liked-android-task-list-any-do-comes-to-iphone-and-chrome/|title=Well-Liked Android Task List Any.DO Comes to iPhone and Chrome|last=Gannes|first=Liz|date=June 4, 2012|publisher=All Things D}} In November 2013, the company released a study revealing the mobile habits of their most productive “super users”.{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/229897|title=5 Habits of Productivity App Super Users|last=|first=|date=Nov 18, 2013|website=|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=Dec 23, 2013}} == Products == === Any.do app === Any.do’s namesake to-do list app was released first on Android, and had 500,000 downloads in its first 30 days after launch.{{cite web|last=Perez|first=Sarah|title=Any.DO Launches A Social To Do List App With $1 Million In Funding|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/11/10/any-do-launches-a-social-to-do-list-app-with-1-million-in-funding/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=Nov 10, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Schonfeld|first=Erick|title=Any.DO Android App Downloaded 500,000 Times In 30 Days|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/12/12/any-do-android-500000/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=Dec 12, 2011}} It was later released on iOS in June 2012 and reached another milestone with 100,000 iPhone downloads in its first day on the platform.{{cite web|last=Perez|first=Sarah|title=Any.DO’s To-Do List App Hits 100,000 iOS Downloads In 24 Hours|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/05/any-dos-to-do-list-app-hits-100000-ios-downloads-in-24-hours/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=Jun 5, 2012}} By November 2016 they hit 15 million users.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/11/dos-assistant-puts-robot-work-list/|title=Any.do’s Assistant Puts a Chat Bot to Work on Your To Do List|last=Pierce|first=David|newspaper=WIRED|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-17}} ==== Functions ==== ''To-do list / Task management:'' * Create, edit, delete tasks and lists{{cite web|last=Messieh|first=Nancy|title=Any.DO is the only productivity Android app you’ll ever need|url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2011/12/19/any-do-is-the-only-productivity-android-app-youll-ever-need/#!pYFs1|publisher=The Next Web|date=Dec 19, 2011}} * Share lists and assign tasks{{cite web|last=Piltch|first=Avram|title=Any.DO App Beams Tasks to Friends, Follows Up on Missed Calls|url=http://blog.laptopmag.com/any-do-app-beams-tasks-to-friends-follows-up-on-missed-calls|publisher=LAPTOP Magazine|date=March 1, 2012}} * Voice input, including integration with Siri and Amazon Echo.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/10/13/13268142/amazon-echo-alexa-any-do-integration|title=Amazon's Echo gets proper to-do support with new Any.Do integration|last=Seifert|first=Dan|newspaper=The Verge|access-date=2016-11-18}} * Auto-suggest feature with predictive text{{cite web|last=Duffy|first=Jill|title=Any.do (for iPhone)|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2405688,00.asp|publisher=PC Mag|date=June 7, 2013}} * Reminders - one time, recurring and location-based reminders * Real-time sync across all of a user’s devices *Missed Call feature (Android Only) *Grocery list / Shopping list feature that: **Sorts your items by aisles (yes, really!) - Allow you to create multiple lists for different stores - Auto-detects grocery items and allows you to move them to the right list - Makes it easy to share your grocery lists with anyone - Copy online recipe ingredients into your clipboard and the list would help you import and sort them automatically - Already works in 10 different languages - Works seamlessly with Alexa Shopping list / Alexa Grocery list. ''Prioritization/planning:'' * The Any.do Moment prompts users to make a habit of morning task planning. (Created after the founders found this to be a common practice among highly productive users of the app.) {{cite web|last=Baer|first=Drake|title=When do apps become rituals?|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3010346/work-smart/when-do-apps-become-rituals|publisher=Fast Company|date=June 3, 2013}} * Using drag and drop tasks and lists can be reordered, and given different levels of priority * Task notifications can be snoozed. ''Calendar (new in v4.0, replacing the separate Cal app):'' * Daily, weekly, and monthly view of combined tasks and events. * Integrates with phone calendar and Facebook calendar * Assign tasks to calendar events and merge to-do items with specific meetings.{{cite web|last=Henry|first=Alan|title=Cal, the Calendar App from the Team at Any.DO, Is Available Now|url=http://lifehacker.com/cal-the-calendar-app-from-the-team-at-any-do-is-avail-736478100|publisher=Lifehacker|date=July 11, 2013}} *Calendar widget ''Delegating to an Assistant (new in v4.0)'' * The Any.do Assistant uses an algorithm to scan to-do lists for items it can help with, marking the tasks directly on the screen. If the user wants, they tap the Assistant symbol and get connected to a combination of AI bots and supervising humans to get tasks like getting groceries or cleaning the house done for them. === Cal app (deprecated) === Any.do released their second app, Cal for iPhone, in July 2013.{{cite web|url=http://gigaom.com/2013/07/11/book-an-appointment-to-the-app-store-any-dos-cal-just-launched-for-ios/|title=Book an appointment to the App Store: Any.Do’s Cal just launched for iOS|last=Tofel|first=Kevin C.|date=July 11, 2013|publisher=GigaOm}} Cal for Android was later released in December 2013.{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2013/12/04/dos-cal-smart-calendar-app-lands-android/|title=Any.do’s Cal smart calendar app lands on Android|last=Yeung|first=Ken|date=Dec 4, 2013|publisher=The Next Web}} Like Any.do, Cal is an interactive, gesture-based calendar app with social integrations. Unlike other calendar apps, Cal helps users focus on the immediate schedule of their day and find pockets of free time for personal use.{{cite web|last=Fiegerman|first=Seth|title=Any.DO's Calendar App Helps You Find More Free Time|url=http://mashable.com/2013/07/11/any-do-calendar/|publisher=Mashable|date=July 11, 2013}} Cal’s scheduling and productivity features include: * Instant location recommendations based on meeting address{{cite web|last=Grey|first=Melissa|title=With Cal, Any.DO hopes to bring its productivity magic to calendars (hands-on)|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/07/11/anydo-cal-hands-on/|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=Dec 23, 2013|date=July 2013}} * Auto-suggest feature with predictive text * Google and Waze map integrations{{cite web|last=Moon|first=Mariella|title=Any.DO's Cal app scores Uber, Waze and Google Maps integration (updated)|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/10/08/any-do-cal-app-uber-waze-google-maps/|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=Dec 23, 2013|date=Oct 2013}} * Uber feature for booking a ride to meetings{{cite web|last=Pinola|first=Melanie|title=Cal from Any.DO Now Integrates with Google Maps, Waze, Amazon and More|url=http://lifehacker.com/cal-from-any-do-now-integrates-with-google-maps-waze-1442476386|publisher=Lifehacker|date=Oct 8, 2013}} * Cloud sync across all of a user’s devices * Amazon and Gifts.com integration for buying event gifts (iPhone only) Cal also integrates with the original Any.do task app and allows users to automatically populate their calendars with relevant tasks by date and event.{{cite web|last=Nieva|first=Richard|title=Any.do announces Cal, a proudly not-so-smart calendar app|url=http://pando.com/2013/06/06/any-do-announces-cal-a-proudly-not-so-smart-calendar-app/|publisher=PandoDaily|date=June 6, 2013}} == Design == On October 9, 2013, The Verge reported Any.do to be the one of the main inspirations behind Jony Ive’s [[iOS 7]] redesign, and others have noted its similarities to the revamped Apple operating system.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/10/9/4817146/taskmasters-how-israeli-intelligence-officers-helped-inspire-the-look-of-ios-7|title=Taskmasters: how Israeli intelligence officers helped inspire the look of iOS 7|last=Newton|first=Casey|date=Oct 9, 2013|publisher=The Verge}}{{cite web|last=Fiegerman|first=Seth|title=iOS 7 Updates Look a Little Too Familiar to Some Apple Developers|url=http://mashable.com/2013/06/11/ios-7-developers/|publisher=Mashable|date=June 11, 2013}} == Funding == Any.do announced $1 million in angel funding in November 2011. By May 2013 the company had raised $3.5 million from [[Genesis Partners]], [[Eric Schmidt]]’s Innovation Endeavors, [[Blumberg Capital]], Joe Lonsdale of [[Palantir Technologies]], Brian Koo of [[Formation 8]], Joe Greenstein of [[Flixter]], and Felicis Ventures.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/13/intelligent-to-do-list-app-any-do-raises-3-5-million-will-further-expand-into-personal-productivity-space/|title=Intelligent To Do List App Any.DO Raises $3.5 Million, Will Further Expand Into Personal Productivity Space|last=Perez|first=Sarah|date=May 13, 2013|publisher=TechCrunch}} The company raised additional unannounced funding from a group of strategic investors including [[Jerry Yang (entrepreneur)|Jerry Yang]] of AME Cloud Ventures and [[Steve Chen]] of YouTube, among others, by October of that same year. == See also == * [[Calendaring software]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website|www.any.do}} * [https://web.any.do/ Any.do Web app] {{Task management software}} {{Calendaring software}} [[Category:Calendaring software]] [[Category:Mobile software]] [[Category:Task management software]] [[Category:Software companies of Israel]] [[Category:Companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Companies based in Tel Aviv]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Bernard McGlinchey | nationality = [[Irish people|Irish]] | smallimage = | office = | term_start = | term_end = | birth_date = {{birth date|1932|10|18|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|2013|4|11|1932|10|18|df=y}} | death_place = [[Kilmacrennan]], [[County Donegal]] | constituency = | party = [[Fianna Fáil]] | spouse = Liz<ref name=pioneering_electoral_strategist/> | partner = Kathleen Sweeney<ref name=pioneering_electoral_strategist/><!--For those with a domestic partner and not married--> | children = Five | education = [[Saint Eunan's College]] |}} '''Bernard McGlinchey''' (18 October 1932 – 11 April 2013) was an [[Irish people|Irish]] businessman and [[Fianna Fáil]] politician.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldemocrat.ie/news/local/death-of-a-political-legend-bernard-mcglinchey-80-dies-at-his-home-1-4991481|title=Death of a political legend - Bernard McGlinchey (80) dies at his home|newspaper=Donegal Democrat|date=11 April 2013|accessdate=11 April 2013}}</ref> He was a member of [[Seanad Éireann]] from 1961 to 1981, and from 1982 to 1983.
==Early life== McGlinchey was born to Patrick McGlinchey and his wife Sarah (née O'Boyle) in 1932 and educated at [[Saint Eunan's College]]. He had six older siblings and one younger one: brothers Danny, Gerry, John, PJ and Tim and sisters Eileen and Jo.<ref name=pioneering_electoral_strategist/>
He was expelled from secondary school.<ref name=pioneering_electoral_strategist/>
==Business career== A restaurant proprietor, McGlinchey founded the [[Grill Music Venue|Golden Grill Nightclub]], renowned as the unofficial Fianna Fáil headquarters and host to party conventions.<ref name=dd_death/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/fianna-fail-favourite-haunt-the-golden-grill-to-reopen-1484236.html|title=Fianna Fáil favourite haunt the Golden Grill 'to reopen'|newspaper=Irish Independent|publisher=Independent News & Media|date=27 September 2008}}</ref> He was a [[millionaire]].<ref name=lover_drunk_minister_doctor/>
==Political career== McGlinchey was first elected to the Seanad by the [[Industrial and Commercial Panel]] in 1961.<ref name=oireachtas_db>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtas.ie/members-hist/default.asp?housetype=1&HouseNum=16&MemberID=1489&ConstID=210|title=Mr. Bernard McGlinchey|work=Oireachtas Members Database|accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> At the 1973 election, he was elected by the [[Administrative Panel]], and he was [[Nominated members of Seanad Éireann|nominated by the Taoiseach]] in 1977. He did not contest the 1981 election, but in 1982 he was nominated by the Taoiseach to the [[16th Seanad]].<ref name=oireachtas_db/>
At the start of his political career McGlinchey was closely linked with [[Neil Blaney]]. Paul M. Sacks, an American academic, wrote a book called ''The Donegal Mafia'' which detailed the actions of the two and their team.<ref name=pioneering_electoral_strategist>{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/people/obituary-bernard-mcglinchey-1.1381991|title=Obituary: Bernard McGlinchey - Former senator and pioneering electoral strategist for Fianna Fáil|work=The Irish Times|date=4 May 2013}}</ref>
He once debated for 12 hours, a Seanad Éireann record for the longest speech.<ref name=dd_death/>
McGlinchey stood for election to [[Dáil Éireann]] in the constituencies of [[Donegal North-East (Dáil constituency)|Donegal North-East]] ([[Irish general election, 1973|1973]], [[Irish general election, 1981|1981]], [[Irish general election, November 1982|November 1982]]) and [[Donegal (Dáil constituency)|Donegal]] ([[Irish general election, 1977|1977]]), but was unsuccessful each time.<ref name=elecs_irl>{{cite web|url=http://www.electionsireland.org/candidate.cfm?ID=3004|title=Bernard McGlinchey|work=ElectionsIreland.org|accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> He was a member of [[Donegal County Council]] for the [[Letterkenny]] area until 2004.<ref name=elecs_irl/>
McGlinchey is said to have "practically invented as a politician" [[Jim McDaid]], selecting "the young, presentable McDaid" and setting him on the path for a career in national politics.<ref name=lover_drunk_minister_doctor>{{cite news|first=Liam|last=Collins|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/lover-drunk-minister-now-doctor-again-26411171.html|title=Lover, drunk, minister now doctor again|work=Sunday Independent|date=30 April 2006}}</ref> McDaid achieved what McGlinchey could not, being elected to the Dáil on his first attempt at the [[Irish general election, 1989|1989 general election]], eventually serving in government, as Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation between 1997 and 2002 and as Minister of State for Transport between 2002 and 2004, and being re-elected to the Dáil at every subsequent election until his retirement in 2010.
==Personal life== McGlinchey married Elizabeth and had five children: three daughters and two sons.<ref name=pioneering_electoral_strategist/> One of his daughters, Adrienne McGlinchey, featured in the national media in 2002 in relation to the [[Death of John Carthy|Carty Inquiry]]. She was born in 1965 in Letterkenny and shared a flat in [[Buncrana]] between 1991 and 1995 with Yvonne Devine, a Letterkenny woman who had been employed by a restaurant run by McGlinchey family members in the town. Adrienne McGlinchey was arrested several times in this period, though records seem to exist mainly of one arrest in July 1991. A garda sergeant acquainted with her described her as "a [[Walter Mitty]] type of person".<ref>{{cite news|first=Anita|last=Guidera|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/three-to-play-major-role-as-stories-inextricably-linked-26026200.html|title=Three to play major role as stories 'inextricably linked'|work=Irish Independent|date=5 November 2002}}</ref>
Bernard McGlinchey died at home, aged 80, on 11 April 2013.<ref name=dd_death>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldaily.com/2013/04/11/sadness-across-donegal-at-death-of-renowned-politician-bernard-mcglinchey/|title=Sadness across Donegal at death of renowned politician Bernard McGlinchey|work=Donegal Daily|date=11 April 2013|accessdate=11 April 2013}}</ref> At the time of his death his partner was Kathleen Sweeney.<ref name=pioneering_electoral_strategist/>
==Eponyms== [[Letterkenny Town Park]] is named after McGlinchey.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldaily.com/2012/05/15/parking-market-square-mayors-plaque-and-tidy-towns-letterkenny-town-council-wrap-up/|title=Transcript from meeting of Letterkenny Town Council|work=Donegal Daily|date=15 May 2012|accessdate=15 May 2012|quote=(ii) Could the Council provide directional signage for the Lawn Bowling Facility at Bernard McGlinchey Park? ANSWER: A sign can be erected at the entrance to Bernard McGlinchey Town Park for the bowling club.}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Members of the 16th Seanad}} {{Members of the 14th Seanad}} {{Members of the 13th Seanad}} {{Members of the 12th Seanad}} {{Members of the 11th Seanad}} {{Members of the 10th Seanad}}

{{Infobox company | name = '''Bertagni 1882 S.p.A.''' | logo = [[File:Bertagni-logo.png|center|185px]] | type = [[Società per azioni]] | genre = | foundation = 1882 in [[Bologna]] | founder = | location_city = [[Arcugnano]] [[Vicenza|VI]] | location_country = [[Italy]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | industry = [[Italian cuisine|Italian food]] | products = [[Food]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | owner = | company_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.bertagni.it www.bertagni.it] | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''Bertagni''' is an [[Italian cuisine|Italian food]] company founded in [[Bologna]] by [[Luigi Bertagni]] in 1882.
==History== [[File:Scatolina-tortellini-bertagni.png|thumb|left|125px|Tortellini pack.]]
The birth of "Pastificio Bertagni" was in 1882 in the workshop of Luigi Bertagni in [[Bologna]]. Luigi Bertagni, with his brothers Ferdinando and Oreste, not only made quality fresh [[tortellini]], but also studied a method in order to package and conserve them, and thus Luigi developed his business.<ref>MAIOLI, Giorgio - ROVERSI, Giancarlo, Sua maestà il tortellino, Re Enzo editrice, 1993.</ref><ref name="bologna-tra-storia-e-osterie">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Nm_qI9uQvcC&pg=PA80&lpg=PA80&dq=pastificio+bertagni++bologna&source=bl |title=Bologna tra storia e osterie: viaggio nelle tradizioni enogastronomiche petroniane... - Alessandro Molinari Pradelli ed. Pendragon 2001.}}</ref>
Thanks to the entrepreneurial spirit of Bertagni brothers, their tortellini was appreciated more and more in Italy and abroad. The Bertagni brothers entered their pastas in numerous World Fairs, winning the bronze medal at The World’s Fair in Paris in 1889 and at The Chicago Fair in 1894, and the gold medal in St. Louis in 1904.
Pastificio Bertagni continued its rapid growth and by the beginning of the 20th century was a well known pasta producer. The ''Bologna Commercial Guide'' described the company: "[[Tortellini]] from Bologna, whose fame went across the seas, by all the gourmets are reputed astoundingly good! It is the Bologna company Bertagni that holds the record of this production and sells tortellini all over the world."<ref name="bologna-tra-storia-e-osterie" />
In 1986 the respected gastronomic critic Corby Kummer declared: Bertagni specialty filled pastas... are excellent and are the closest thing to having a pasta store down the street.<ref>Corby Kummer, ''The Atlantic Monthly'', July 1986.</ref>
In 2002 the company was sold to [[Food|pasta industry]] veterans, resulting in a great increase in sales, carrying its [[Pasta|filled pasta]] specialities onto the tables of the [[world]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bertagni.it|title=History, in Bertagni.it.}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Italy|Companies}}
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://www.bertagni.it Bertagni web site.]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Business Centre Australia | image = CNBC Australia - Business Centre Australia logo.png | caption = | camera = | picture_format = | audio_format = | runtime = | creator = | developer = | producer = | executive_producer = | presenter = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = [[Singapore]]
Australia | location = | language = English | network = [[CNBC Asia]], [[CNBC Australia]] | first_aired = 2001-01-01 | last_aired = 2004-01-02 | num_series = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[Business Center (CNBC Asia)|Business Center]] | related = | website = }} '''''Business Centre Australia''''' was once one of [[CNBC Asia]]'s business news shows to round-up the trading day in Australia. During its debut in late January 2001, it initially aired only to viewers on CNBC Asia's Australian feed but later that year it was made available across the region. The show was presented by [[Amanda Drury]] from Singapore and [[Mark Laudi]] from Sydney although Laudi eventually moved back to Singapore and co-hosted the show there. {{CNBC Asia Business Day}} [[Category:CNBC Asia programs]] [[Category:CNBC Australia programmes]] [[Category:Australian television news programmes]] [[Category:Australian television talk shows]] [[Category:2000s Australian television series]] [[Category:2001 Australian television series debuts]] [[Category:2004 Australian television series endings]] [[Category:Business-related television series]] {{News-tv-prog-stub}}

A '''business partner''' is a commercial entity with which another commercial entity has some form of [[Business alliance|alliance]]. This relationship may be a [[contract]]ual, exclusive bond in which both entities commit not to ally with third parties. Alternatively, it may be a very loose arrangement designed largely to impress customers and competitors with the size of the network the business partners belong to.
== Business mating (partnership formation) == A business partner or alliance can be crucial for businesses. However, businesses can not choose business partners in any way they want. In many instances, the potential partner might not be interested in forming a business relationship, also known as business mating. It is important that both sides of the agreement complement each other, but also that there are some common ground. For example, in management style, mindset, and also technology. If, for example, management style would be too different between the firms then a partnership could be problematic. Kask and Linton (2013) <ref>Kask and Linton (2013) Business mating: when start-ups get it right http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08276331.2013.876765#.U0UEcfl_t8F</ref> investigate under what conditions business mating (formation) takes place for startup firms seeking business partners.
== Differentiation == The meaning of the term is quite different from that implied in [[partnership]], and it is because of the potential for confusion between the two that widespread use of 'business partner' has been discouraged at times in the past.
A business partner can be: # A [[Distribution (business)|supplier]] # A [[customer]] # A channel intermediary (such as an [[agent (law)|agent]] or [[reseller]]), or # A vendor of complementary offerings (for example, one party sells the hardware, while the other sells the software) This is a wider definition than a [[business alliance]].
A Business Partner is becoming more common in HR departments as it represents the employees position, ideally seeing the HR issues from the employers and employees point of view. Small and medium business are often turning to external HR Business Partners to solve any HR disputes.
== Cohesion == One example of a business partnership is the "Agility Alliance" originated by [[Electronic Data Systems]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eds.com/services/alliances/agility/ |title=Agility Alliance | HP Services |publisher=Eds.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Members of this IT-focused alliance include [[Microsoft]], [[Oracle Corporation]], [[Sun Microsystems]] and [[SAP AG|SAP]]. This highlights two problems with multi-party partnerships: * Two of the companies may be partners with a third member of the partnership, but highly aggressive towards each other. (Oracle and SAP compete against each other in the [[Enterprise resource planning|ERP]] market.) * One party may be partner to a second party when targeting one market, but competitive against that same company when targeting another market. (Microsoft may be happy to work with Sun when Sun is offering its servers, but far less happy when Sun is proposing [[OpenOffice.org]], in contention with Microsoft Office.)
== Business partner search == '''Business partner search''' or '''business matchmaking''' is the process/service of finding buyers/customers, distributors, licensees, and/or other business partners. This can be provided as a paid service by a commercial organization, or as a free service by the commercial section of a country's embassy/consulate or an association of businesses in a particular area.
Customarily commercial consideration of this service is a one time fee. Fee of this service depends on the business domain, the volume of business of both partners that will end up in a partnership relation as the end result of this service, etc.
In a specific example of a specific domain this fee is found between EUR 1800~2200 depending on the tasks required from the business matchmaker.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www-1.ibm.com/partnerworld/pwhome.nsf/weblook/index.html IBM's Business Partner website] * [http://www.sanverhosting.com/rediff/ RediffMail Business Partner website] * [http://www.sanverhosting.com/google-apps/google-business-email/ Google Apps for Work Premier Partner website] * [http://welcome.hp.com/country/uk/en/features/parthership_2004.html HP on its strategic partnership with BT] * [http://www.btglobalservices.com/business/global/en/about_us/partnerships/index.html BT on its strategic partnerships with Nortel, Accenture, Microsoft etc] * [http://www.emergeskills.com/Partner%20with%20Us.html Emerge Vocational Skills - Business partners Web Page]
[[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Partnerships]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=December 2017}} The '''[[DLF (company)|DLF]] Cyber City''' is a [[Business park|corporate park]] in [[Gurgaon]], India, which houses some of the top IT & [[Fortune 500]] companies.<ref name=toi1>{{cite web|title='Cyber city' Gurgaon finally gets a public transport|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/gurgaon/Cyber-city-Gurgaon-finally-gets-a-public-transport/articleshow/25662218.cms|publisher=The Times of India|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> It has been termed a "futuristic commercial hub".<ref>{{cite web|title=The Gurgaon story: A mirror to India's growth|url=http://www.ndtv.com/gurgaon-news/the-gurgaon-story-a-mirror-to-indias-growth-458043|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> Cyber City is considered one of the largest hubs of IT activity in Delhi-NCR. It lies near [[Udyog Vihar]], which is a conventional industrial area on the opposite side of NH-8. Cyber Hub, which is primarily an eating area with a large number of leading restaurants besides a few shops is located next to Cyber city and caters primarily to the people working in DLF Cyber City.
==Transport== In 2013, [[Rapid Metro Gurgaon]] was introduced to Cyber City, connecting it with [[Delhi Metro]].<ref name=toi1/> There are six operational stations within the Cyber City. The National Highway 8 (NH-8) runs through Cyber City and a project to construct a 16-lane expressway is also under progress.<ref>{{cite web|title=Diversion, rain trigger Cyber City chaos|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/gurgaon/Diversion-rain-trigger-Cyber-City-chaos/articleshow/48152626.cms|publisher=The Times of India|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> A flyover between Cyber City and MG Road was opened in 2015 to reduce traffic congestion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Flyover brings Cyber City closer to MG Road|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/gurgaon/Flyover-brings-Cyber-City-closer-to-MG-Road/articleshow/46892646.cms|publisher=The Times of India|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> The [[Indira Gandhi International Airport]] is located in close proximity to the Cyber City.
==Entertainment== Cyber city is surrounded by 26 shopping malls, seven golf courses and several luxury shops selling productions from international brands such as Chanel and Louis Vuitton. Mercedes Benzes and BMWs shimmer in automobile showrooms. Cyber Hub is a massive courtyard within cyber city. DLF Cyberhub has an area of about 2,00,000 sq ft, and 3 levels floors. It has cafes, restaurants, pubs,a standup comedy venue, The people & co., and a Broadway style theatre. There is an open-air amphitheater that plays host to weekend cultural & art shows and rock concerts.<ref>{{cite web|title=DLF Cyberhub - About us|publisher=HaloBee |url=https://www.halobee.com/mall/dlf-cyber-hub-gurgaon/|}}</ref>[[File:Gurgoan6.JPG|thumb|right|Gateway Tower in Cyber City]] [[File:Cyber Green Building, Gurgaon, Haryana, India - 20070613.jpg|thumb|right|Cyber Green building]] [[File:Gurgoan5.JPG|thumb|right| A commercial area in DLF Cyber City]]
==See also== *[[Electronic City]] *[[HITEC City]] *[[Hinjawadi]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.dlfcybercity.com Official Website of DLF Cyber City]
{{coord missing|Haryana}}
