revision.comment: qualifying the definition: "phostic" is not Greek ("photic" would be the correct form)
revision.text:
{{POV check|date=June 2012}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2011}} '''Theophostic Counseling''' was developed in the United States during the mid-1990s Ed Smith, a Baptist minister.<ref>[http://www.equip.org/articles/theophostic-prayer-ministry-part-one-/ "Theophostic Prayer Ministry (Part One) – Christian Prayer, Occult Visualization, or Secular Psychotherapy?"], ''Christian Research Journal'', volume 29, number 3 (2006)</ref> After concerns about legal liabilities associated with offering counseling services, Smith later changed the name to '''Theophostic Prayer Ministry'''.<ref>[http://www.theophostic.com/resources/1/pdf/PST001.pdf], "Christian Research Institute" Position Paper: PST001, p.8</ref>
Its name comes from the Greek ''theo'' (God) and quasi-Greek ''phostic'' (light), and it is often associated with the Christian [[Inner Healing Movement]]. Smith says people are being delivered from phobias, depressions, anxiety disorders, [[obsessive–compulsive disorder]]s, dissociative personality disorders, attention deficit hyperactivity disorders, sexual addictions, eating disorders, post-traumatic stress disorders, and homosexuality through Theophostic principles. The name Theophostic is a registered trademark.<ref>[http://www.theophostic.com/aboutus.aspx]''Business Information'' paragraph on ''About Us'' page of www.theophostic.com</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2001/february5/19.18.html?start=2 |title=''Christianity Today'', February 5, 2001 |publisher=Christianitytoday.com |date=February 5, 2001 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref>
Few empirical evaluations of Theophostic Ministry are available, although Christian psychologist Fernando Garzon says that current case study and survey data has yielded clinically significant changes in client symptom levels, and high degrees of client and practitioner satisfaction.<ref>[https://www.counseling.org/knowledge-center/vistas/by-year2/vistas-2004/docs/default-source/vistas/vistas_2004_26 Cognitive restructuring through contemplative inner healing prayer.] ''VISTAS: Perspectives on Counseling'' American Counseling Association Press, Garzon, F. (2004).]</ref>
== Definition == Smith's definition of Theophostic Prayer Ministry is that "Theophostic is a ministry of helping emotionally wounded people to acknowledge and to identify the true source of their inner emotional pain and find lasting peace through receiving personalized truth directly from the Lord."<ref name="Smith 2004">Smith, Ed M. ''Freedom from Performance-based Spirituality'', DVD, Theophostic Prayer Ministry (2004)</ref>
== Principles == Smith lists fourteen basic principles of Theophostic Prayer Ministry,:<ref>Smith, Edward M. ''Healing Life’s Hurts through Theophostic Prayer'', p. 39, New Creation Publishing (2002, 2005)</ref>
1. Our present situation is rarely the cause of our ongoing emotional pain.
2. Everything we presently know, feel or are mentally aware of has its roots in a first-time experience.
3. If we try to resolve our present conflicts without resolving our historical lie-based woundedness, we will find only temporary relief for our emotional pain. However, if we find renewal for our past, we can redeem our present.
4. Since many of the negative emotions we currently feel are reflections of the past, they provide opportunities for the wounds of our lives to be exposed and thus for renewal to occur.
5. To facilitate emotional renewal, we need to identify the three basic elements in the renewal process: (1) the present emotional pain, (2) the original memory container and (3) the original lie(s) implanted in the memory container.
6. People are in emotional bondage due to two basic factors, belief and choice. These two factors are rooted in the context of deception.
7. When we believe a lie, the outcome will often have much the same consequences as though it were true.
8. To be free of the lies we believe, we must identify and own the lies rather than suppress or deny we believe them before we can be free from them.
9. In the midst of our “darkness”, we must come to realize how utterly bound we are to the lie and how helpless we are to overcome its debilitating grip on our lives apart from God’s divine intervention.
10. No person, including ourselves, is capable of talking us out of the lies we believe. We will be free only when we receive the truth from the One who is Truth (John 14:6, "I am the way, and the truth, and the life").
11. When we know the truth experientially, having received truth from God in our memory experience, we can walk in genuine maintenance-free victory in these areas of our lives.
12. In time of crisis or in emotionally charged life situations, our experiential knowledge tends to override our logical truth.
13. Lie-based pain can only be removed as the lies causing the pain are replaced with truth, whereas, sin-based pain can only be dealt with through the cross of Jesus.
14. Mind renewal is a lifelong process.
== The Theophostic Prayer Ministry Process == Participants in a typical Theophostic Prayer Ministry session are the ministry recipient, a ministry facilitator and optionally a prayer partner.<ref>Smith 2007, p.82, 202.</ref>
The ministry facilitator ensures that the ministry recipient understands the process before the session begins.<ref>Garzon, Fernando, Psy.D., Editor (2008). ''Pursuing Peace – Case Studies Exploring the Effectiveness of Theophostic Prayer Ministry'', p. 59. Xulon Press. {{ISBN|978-1-60647-202-6}}.</ref><ref>Smith 2007, p.88</ref>
The facilitator begins the session with a prayer of encouragement.<ref>Smith 2007, p.93, 225</ref>
The ministry recipient closes his eyes and concentrates on feeling the emotional pain from which he is seeking relief. The purpose of focusing on the emotion is to allow his mind to drift back to a related memory<ref name="CRJ2">[http://www.equip.org/articles/theophostic-prayer-ministry-part-one-/ "Theophostic Prayer Ministry (Part One) – Christian Prayer, Occult Visualization, or Secular Psychotherapy?"], ''Christian Research Journal'', volume 29, number 3 (2006).</ref> . That memory is of a situation that the recipient regards as painful and which he has interpreted to form a belief about himself or his situation.<ref name="CRJ2" /> The event that is contained in the memory may have occurred many years ago, for example in the person’s childhood.<ref name="CRJ2" /> The emotion provides a bridge to the belief.<ref>Smith, Edward M. (2007). ''Theophostic Prayer Ministry, Basic Training Seminar 2007, DVD Sessions, Disk 1, New Creation Publishing.</ref>
The ministry recipient describes the memory to the facilitator.<ref name="CRJ2" /> The facilitator asks the recipient some questions that will enable the recipient to drill down to the core belief housed in this memory that is troubling him. The questions are not [[leading question]]s,<ref>Smith, Edward M. ''Healing Life’s Hurts through Theophostic Prayer'', Theophostic Prayer Ministry Guidelines, p. 256, New Creation Publishing (2002, 2005)</ref> as the facilitator does not assume anything about the memory’s content. Rather they are open questions, posed to help the recipient himself to identify the core belief. This core belief is known in TPM parlance as a “lie” that causes lie-based pain. The lie arises from the recipient’s interpretation of the situation.<ref>Smith, Edward M. ''Healing Life’s Hurts through Theophostic Prayer'', p. 145, New Creation Publishing (2002, 2005)</ref> For example, a rape victim may have formed a belief that she is dirty or shameful, whereas she was actually an innocent victim. Though her belief is false, it has the same impact on her emotional state now as if it were true.<ref>Smith 2007, p.19</ref>
Once the recipient has identified the core troublesome belief, the facilitator prays, asking the Lord Jesus to provide the recipient with his perspective, that is, what he would like the recipient to know.<ref name="Smith 2004" /><ref name="CRJ2" /> The Lord answers that prayer in various ways. He might provide his truth to the recipient by means of a mental picture, a feeling, a scripture, a word, a realization or some other way.<ref name="CRJ2" /> The truth received from Jesus replaces the painful lie previously believed.<ref name="CRJ2" /> The result is peace.<ref>Smith 2007, p.23</ref><ref>Garzon 2008, p. 77</ref>
Every person believes not just one, but many lies of the kind that lead to present emotional pain. Each lie can be eliminated with the same process.<ref name="CRJ2" />
== Research == In his 2008 book,<ref>Garzon 2008</ref> Dr. Fernando Garzon, an associate professor in the Center for Counselling and Family Studies at Liberty University,<ref>Garzon 2008, p. 94</ref> describes his team’s two-year-long outcomes-based case study research project that evaluated TPM. The research team found very clear preliminary results that showed a correlation between TPM treatment and symptom reductions.<ref name="Garzon 2008, p. 93">Garzon 2008, p. 93</ref> Garzon wrote that the case studies strongly support the need for randomized comparative or control group studies.<ref name="Garzon 2008, p. 93" />
Garzon had conducted preliminary practitioner studies in 2001 which showed promise, concluding that "...outcome-based case studies and randomized clinical trials should proceed on TPM to ascertain whether the therapeutic perception of efficacy displayed in this survey actually has merit..." He also found that a wide variety of people were practicing Theophostic Ministry at that time, including pastors, lay counselors, and psychologists. According to Garzon, this raised questions about some practitioners' level of training.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/h6x88387wv80341r/ |title=Theophostic Ministry: Preliminary Practitioner Survey – ''Pastoral Psychology'', Volume 53 Number May 5, 2005, Fernando Garzon and Margaret Poloma |issn=0031-2789 |accessdate=April 18, 2011 |doi=10.1007/s11089-005-2582-1 |volume=53 |issue=5 |journal=Pastoral Psychology |pages=387–396}}</ref>
== Controversy == A Kentucky journalist has associated Theophostic Prayer Ministry with [[Recovered Memory Therapy]], an approach now widely discredited after discovery of false memory phenomena<ref name=Brandon1997>{{cite journal | author = Brandon, S. |author2=Boakes, J. |author3=Glaser, D. |author4=Green, R. |author5=MacKeith, J. |author6= Whewell, P. | year = 1997 | title = Reported recovered memories of child sexual abuse: Recommendations for good practice and implications for training, continuing professional development and research | journal = Psychiatric Bulletin | volume = 21 | pages = 663–665 | doi = 10.1192/pb.21.10.663 | issue = 10}}</ref> on the basis that Theophostic Prayer Ministry also presupposes the possibility of repression or [[Memory inhibition#Evidence against inhibition in memory|memory inhibition]],<ref>Controversial international ministry operates from Campbellsville – Central Kentucky News Journal, July 2, 2003 by Jan Fletcher</ref> A critical entry from [[Ontario Consultants on Religious Tolerance]] also seeks to associate Theophostic Ministry with [[Recovered Memory Therapy]], although the article does not identify the aspects of Theophostic Prayer Ministry that merit the assertion. It also claims that Theophostic Prayer Ministry has added beliefs about [[demonic possession]], [[Satanic abuse|Satanic influence]], direct communication with "[[Jesus Christ]] or the Holy Spirit" and "unique concepts about the inner workings of the mind".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org//theophostic.htm |title=Menu: Theophostic Counseling |publisher=Religioustolerance.org |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org//theophostic3.htm |title=Theophostic Counseling (TPM) TPM counseling: the process and reaction |publisher=Religioustolerance.org |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref> However, Smith himself strongly repudiates Recovered Memory Therapy,<ref>Smith 2007, p.215</ref> and in recent years he has taught that it is counter-productive to pursue or even allow demonic confrontations in a ministry session.<ref>Smith 2007, p.124-126</ref> However, in his Basic Training Seminar Manual (and in each of the training videos), Smith warns strongly against making any suggestions that might affect the actual content of a memory,<ref>Smith 2007, p.129-133</ref> and he lists ten ways in which TPM differs from RMT.<ref>Smith 2007, p.215-218</ref> Nevertheless, once a core belief about self has been identified through the memory (not in the memory per se), Smith does "invite the Lord" to speak truth to the ministry recipient concerning that belief.<ref>Smith 2007, p.106</ref>
In an article about TPM in the Christian Research Journal,<ref name="CRJ2" /> Elliot Miller said that to accuse TPM of practicing recovered memory therapy and visualization is to betray ignorance or bias against TPM that refuses to be corrected by clear and consistent facts.
A Christian psychologist, David Entwistle, has expressed concerns with its practice: "TPM follows in the lineage of 'healing of memory' techniques, though it departs from that lineage in a number of important respects. Numerous concerns exist surrounding insufficient attempts to ground TPM in biblical concepts; inadequate and often flawed explanations of basic psychological processes; dubious claims about the prevalence of [[Dissociative identity disorder|DID]], [[Satanic ritual abuse|SRA]], and demonic activity; estimates of traumatic abuse that exceed empirical findings; and the failure to sufficiently appreciate the possibility of [[iatrogenic]] memory contamination".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb6566/is_1_32/ai_n29090065/pg_10/?tag=content;col1 |title=Shedding light on Theophostic Ministry 1: practice issues – ''Journal of Psychology and Theology'', Spring 2004, by David N. Entwistle |publisher=Findarticles.com |date=May 14, 2002 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref>
Entwistle raises concern over empirical validity, with questions about literal appearances of God, as Entwistle interprets claimed perceptions of truth, including spontaneous visualizations of Christ; ethical and legal issues relating to guarantees of healing; application of TPM to a variety of mental disorders without empirical validation; the legal question of whether it should be considered a religious intervention or a counseling procedure – and whether this was settled by changing the name from Theophostic Counseling to Theophostic Ministry; and the failure of Smith to welcome public analysis and critique of TPM.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb6566/is_1_32/ai_n29090066/pg_8/?tag=content;col1 |title=Shedding light on Theophostic Ministry 2: ethical and legal issues – ''Journal of Psychology and Theology'', Spring 2004, by David N. Entwistle |publisher=Findarticles.com |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref>
In Cumberland County, Maine, sexual-abuse charges against pastor Thomas Wright were laid after a church member's memory surfaced during Theophostic sessions, of Wright allegedly abusing a child. When the case went to trial in 2002, the charges were thrown out by the District Attorney because evidence was based on ‘unconventional and biased therapeutic methods’. The District Attorney noted that these methods were considered unreliable by the American Psychological Society. In Australia, a psychologist was found guilty of malpractice for using Theophostic methods in 2006 by the Queensland Health Practitioners Tribunal. The tribunal found that Irene Moreau, who practiced from a Christian counselling centre in Brisbane, 'inappropriately used Theophostic Prayer Ministry as a counselling technique'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-130383209.html |title=AAP General News (Australia) Article date: October 25, 2006 |publisher=Highbeam.com |date=October 25, 2006 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}</ref>
Practitioners of inner healing techniques such as TPM frequently do not have formal training in psychology or counseling, although Fernando Garzon suggests that this in many cases may be beneficial, saying: "...it may serve people who might not get help otherwise, cannot afford professional therapy, do not wish to use insurance, or have access to counseling limited by managed care. Others belong to churches in which the pastor is either not trained, not interested, or not available (due to having too many other pastoral duties) to meet the needs for pastoral counseling. Still others simply may trust lay people, whom they know, more than a therapist, whom they do not know. In addition, the training itself may benefit the lay counselors spiritually and emotionally."<ref>Lay Christian Counseling and Client Expectations for Integration in Therapy ''Journal of Psychology and Christianity'' (in press) Garzon et al, Liberty University</ref>
In addition to questions about the efficacy, safety and reliability of TPM, it has also divided Christian observers with regard to the soundness of its theology. In the conclusion of their paper ''A theological analysis of Theophostic Ministry'', Bryan Maier and Philip Monroe put it this way: "...on the issues of sin and healing, the question remains for Christian counselors and the evangelical community as a whole as to whether Smith's "theological basis" is consistent with responsible biblical doctrine. We do not think that Smith has warrant to make this claim. Furthermore, we think these differences are so significant that we advise great caution before engaging in this ministry – whether as a client or as facilitator."<ref name="maier">{{cite journal|last1=Maier|first1=Bryan N.|date=Fall 2003|title=A Theological Analysis Of Theophostic Ministry|url=http://www.galaxie.com/article/trinj24-2-01|journal=[[Trinity Journal (theology)|Trinity Journal]]|volume=24|issue=2|pages=169–188|issn=0360-3032|oclc=2243858|ref=maier}}<!--|publisher=Trinity Evangelical Divinity School--><!--http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=rfh&AN=ATLA0001406507&site=ehost-live&scope=site--></ref>
== References == {{reflist}} *{{cite book | last = Smith | first = Edward M. | title = Theophostic Prayer Ministry: Basic Training Seminar Manual | publisher = New Creation Publishing, Campbellsville, Kentucky | year = 2007 }} *{{cite book | last = Garzon | first = Fernando, Psy.D., Editor | title = Pursuing Peace – Case Studies Exploring the Effectiveness of Theophostic Prayer Ministry | publisher = [[Xulon Press]] | year = 2008 | isbn = 978-1-60647-202-6 }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Theophostic Counseling}} [[Category:Christian movements]] [[Category:Counseling]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Labour relations to [[:Category:Labor relations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{see also|Web hosting service}} [[File:Angry mob of four.jpg|thumb|right|An artist's depiction of a prototypical angry mob staging a revolt]]
A '''user revolt''' is a social conflict in which [[User (system)|users]] of a [[website]] collectively and openly protest a website host's or [[Internet forum#Administrator|administrator's]] instructions for using the website. Sometimes it happens that the website hosts can control a website's use in certain ways, but the hosts also depend on the users to comply with voluntary social rules in order for the website to operate as the hosts would like. A user revolt occurs when the website users protest against the voluntary social rules of a website, and use the website in a way that is in conflict with the wishes of the website host or administrators.
A user revolt is a process starting with a triggering event, then a [[rebellion]], then a response to the rebellion.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mashable.com/2009/05/16/why-revolts-occur/#o9DZjzq0zgq1 |title=Why Social Media Revolts Take Place (and How We Might Prevent Them) |first=Ben |last=Parr |work=mashable.com |date=16 May 2009 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref>
In traditional media like newspapers and television broadcasting, if the media outlet did something to upset readers, they rarely had to fear a hostile audience reaction.<ref name="Douglas 2008">{{cite web |url= http://gawker.com/348607/how-the-internets-biggest-social-news-site-saved-itself-again |title=How The Internet's Biggest Social News Site Saved Itself (Again) |first=Nick |last=Douglas |work=gawker.com |date=24 January 2008 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> This is because in traditional media, the viewers have limited ability to discuss among themselves how to organize to protest the media outlet they are all sharing.<ref name="Douglas 2008"/> Some Internet media outlets differ in that their community of users can easily contact each other, organize, and present a coordinated revolt against any given media company.<ref name="Douglas 2008"/> Sometimes they can even do this using that media company's own hosted forums.<ref name="Douglas 2008"/>
==Distinction from Internet-based activism== [[Internet-based activism]] is sometimes called a user revolt when website users protest the terms of a website while using that website for other purposes.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mashable.com/2011/12/07/social-media-uprising-activism/#P73tMy2p5iqs |title=9 Social Media Uprisings That Sought to Change the World in 2011 |first=Zoe |last=Fox |work=mashable.com |date=7 December 2011 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref>{{clarify||date=December 2015}} A distinction between a user revolt and Internet-based activism could be that in a user revolt, an objective of the protest is to revolt against the website itself. In Internet-based activism, the primary goal of the protest is something other than reforming a website, although websites which create barriers to the larger protest may incidentally experience a user revolt for participating in the larger conflict. An example of a situation in which Internet activism includes a user revolt might be when users wish to engage in prohibited political discussion, but a government compels the website host to censor those discussions. The core conflict in this case is between users and the government, and not that the website itself as a communication medium. However, when the website as a communication medium chooses to create barriers to communication for users, then users of the website organize a user revolt even when the primary objective is something other than a website protest.
Examples of Internet-based activism which led to user revolts include [[Social media and the Arab Spring]] and the [[Twitter Revolution]].
==Triggers== The many triggers of user revolt can be roughly split into three broad categories, including unwelcomed changes to technical features, unwelcomed changes to policies, and heavy handedness of host platforms in dealing with core members.
==Examples==
===Wikipedia===
====Spanish fork==== {{main|Enciclopedia Libre Universal en Español}}
The Enciclopedia Libre was founded by contributors to the [[Spanish Wikipedia|Spanish-language Wikipedia]] who decided to start an independent project. Led by Edgar Enyedy, they left Wikipedia on 26 February 2002, and created the new website, hosted free by the [[University of Seville]], with the freely licensed articles of the Spanish-language Wikipedia.<ref>{{cite news|last=[[Nathaniel Tkacz|Tkacz]]|first=[[Nathaniel Tkacz|Nathaniel]]|title=The Spanish Fork: Wikipedia's ad-fuelled mutiny|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-01/20/wikipedia-spanish-fork|newspaper=Wired UK|date=20 January 2011}}</ref> The split was provoked over concern that Wikipedia would accept advertising.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://networkcultures.org/cpov/2011/01/15/spanish_fork/ |title=‘Good luck with your WikiPAIDia’: Reflections on the 2002 Fork of the Spanish Wikipedia |first=Nathaniel |last=Tkacz |work=networkcultures.org |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> After Wikipedia made a commitment to not use advertising, the Spanish fork attracted no more attention, and was mostly abandoned within a year of its founding.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lih|first1=Andrew|title=The Wikipedia revolution : how a bunch of nobodies created the world's greatest encyclopedia|date=2009|publisher=Hyperion|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4013-0371-6|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AWuZAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT273&lpg=PT273&dq=wikipedia+spanish+fork+advertising&source=bl&ots=Kub6TpjjqF&sig=CgsAYVMbDYRnOglsnJIy_QzioBQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBWoVChMI6bW64r6jxwIVxXE-Ch0HxwDW#v=onepage&q=wikipedia%20spanish%20fork%20advertising&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2015/12/02/wikipedia-has-a-ton-of-money-so-why-is-it-begging-you-to-donate-yours/ |title=Wikipedia has a ton of money. So why is it begging you to donate yours? |first=Caitlin |last=Dewey |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2 December 2015 |publisher=[[Washington Post Company|WPC]] |location=[[Washington, DC|Washington DC]] |issn=0190-8286 |accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>
====VisualEditor==== {{main|VisualEditor}}
''[[The Daily Dot]]'' suggested that the Wikimedia Foundation's pursuit of more users may be at the risk of alienating the existing editors.<ref name="TheDailyDot"/> Some experienced editors have expressed concerns about the rollout and bugs, with the [[German Wikipedia]] community voting overwhelmingly against making the VisualEditor the new default, and expressing a preference for making it an "opt-in" feature instead.<ref name="TheDailyDot"/><ref name="theregister-buggy">{{cite web|work=[[The Register]]|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/08/01/wikipedians_reject_wysiwyg_editor/ |title=Wikipedians say no to Jimmy's 'buggy' WYSIWYG editor |author= Andrew Orlowski|date=2013-08-01 |accessdate=2013-08-05}}</ref> Despite these complaints, the Wikimedia Foundation continued with the rollout to other languages.<ref name="TheDailyDot">{{cite web|work=[[The Daily Dot]]|url=http://www.dailydot.com/business/wikipedia-visual-editor-wysiwyg/ |title=Will Wikipedia's pretty new editing software solve its recruitment crisis? |author= Tim Sampson |date=2012-07-04 |accessdate=2013-07-27}}</ref> ''[[The Register]]'' said, "Our brief exploration suggests it certainly removes any need to so much as remember what kind of parenthesis belongs where."<ref name="TheRegister Sharwood 2013">{{cite web|work=[[The Register]]|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/06/07/wysiwyg_wikipedia_writer_lands_in_july/ |title=Wikimedia edges closer to banishing Wikitext |author= Simon Sharwood|date=2013-06-07 |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> ''[[The Economist]]''{{'}}s L.M., said it is "the most significant change in Wikipedia's short history."<ref name="TheEconomist">{{cite web|work=[[The Economist]]|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/babbage/2011/12/changes-wikipedia |title=Changes at Wikipedia: Seeing things |author= L.M. |date=2011-12-13 |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> ''[[Softpedia]]'' ran an article titled "Wikipedia's New VisualEditor Is the Best Update in Years and You Can Make It Better".<ref name="softpedia-best">{{cite web|work=[[Softpedia]]|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Wikipedia-s-New-VisualEditor-Is-the-Best-Update-in-Years-and-You-Can-Make-It-Better-365072.shtml |title=Wikipedia's New VisualEditor Is the Best Update in Years and You Can Make It Better |author=Lucian Parfeni|date=2013-07-02 |accessdate=2013-07-30}}</ref> Some opponents have said that users may feel belittled by the implication that "certain people" are confused by wiki markup and therefore need the VisualEditor.<ref name="Simonite">{{cite web|url=http://www.technologyreview.com/featuredstory/520446/the-decline-of-wikipedia/|title=The Decline of Wikipedia: Even As More People Than Ever Rely on It, Fewer People Create It|last=Simonite|first=Tom|date=October 22, 2013|work=[[MIT Technology Review]]|accessdate=January 17, 2014}}</ref>
''The Daily Dot'' reported on 24 September 2013 that the Wikimedia Foundation had experienced a mounting backlash from the English Wikipedia community, which criticised the VisualEditor as slow, poorly implemented and prone to break articles' existing text formatting. In the resulting "test of wills" between the community and the Foundation, a single volunteer administrator overrode the Wikimedia Foundation's settings to change the availability of VisualEditor from opt-out to opt-in. The Foundation acquiesced, but vowed to continue developing and improving the VisualEditor.<ref name=thereg>{{cite news|work=[[The Register]]|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/09/25/wikipedia_peasants_revolt/|title=Revolting peasants force Wikipedia to cut'n'paste Visual Editor into the bin|author=Andrew Orlowski|date=2013-09-25|accessdate=2013-10-06}}</ref><ref name="dd-kww">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailydot.com/news/wikipedia-visualeditor-kww-patch/|title=Wikipedia faces revolt over VisualEditor|work=The Daily Dot|author=Tim Sampson|date=2013-09-24|accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref>
====Superprotect==== [[File:WMF building wiki wall in August 2014 caricature.jpg|thumb|right|Satirical cartoon depicting the Wikimedia Foundation building a wall to prevent the volunteer Wikimedia community from participating in Wikipedia]]
"Superprotect" was the name for a [[superuser]] tool granted to [[Wikimedia Foundation]] staff but denied to all Wikimedia community members starting in August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Wikipedia contributors listed in history|title=Wikipedia:Protection policy|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#Superprotect|website=Wikipedia|accessdate=12 January 2016}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=August 2016}} Wikimedia Foundation staff used the tool to force the installation of the Wikimedia Foundation's software against the wishes of the Wikimedia community.<ref name="Lih 2015">{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/21/opinion/can-wikipedia-survive.html |title=Can Wikipedia Survive? |first=Andrew |last=Lih |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=20 June 2015 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="Kleinz 2014">{{cite web |url= http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Wikipedia-Superprotect-Streit-spitzt-sich-zu-2293513.html |title=Wikipedia: Superprotect-Streit spitzt sich zu |first=Torsten |last=Kleinz|work=heise.de |publisher=[[Heinz Heise]] |date=16 August 2014 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> This conflict was unprecedented.<ref name="Lih 2015"/> [[Erik Möller]], then director of the Wikimedia Foundation, managed the Superprotect tool.<ref name="Kleinz 2014"/> The software in dispute was [[MediaViewer]], which was a software feature that guided Wikipedia readers into viewing images in a certain way.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.golem.de/news/superschutz-wikimedia-stiftung-zwingt-deutschen-nutzern-mediaviewer-auf-1408-108522.html |title=Superschutz: Wikimedia-Stiftung zwingt deutschen Nutzern Mediaviewer auf|first=Friedhelm |last=Greis |work=golem.de |date=12 August 2014 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> Wikimedia commentator [[Andrew Lih]] described the superprotect feature as "[[Orwellian]]-sounding".<ref name="Lih 2015"/>
The MediaViewer and Superprotect conflict between the Wikimedia community and the Wikimedia Foundation was called a revolt.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/08/18/class_war_wikipedias_workers_revolt_after_bourgeois_papershufflers_suspend_democracy/ |title=Class war! Wikipedia's workers revolt again |first=Andrew |last=Orlowski |work=[[The Register]] |date=18 August 2014 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> The controversy demonstrated that the Wikimedia Foundation was unable to control the Wikimedia community with technical features, but rather, that mutual understanding and discussion among stakeholders would be required to develop Wikipedia's software.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://netzpolitik.org/2014/kommentar-der-superprotect-streit-in-wikipedia-oder-souveraen-ist-wer-ueber-root-zugriff-verfuegt/ |title=Kommentar: Der "Superprotect"-Streit in Wikipedia, oder: Souverän ist, wer über Root-Zugriff verfügt |first=Leonhard |last=Dobusch |work=[[netzpolitik.org]] |date= 23 August 2014 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref>
The feature was reviewed and discussed by the Wikimedia community.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_Signpost/2014-08-13/News_and_notes |title=Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost News and notes |author=Neotarf |work=en.wikipedia.org |date=13 August 2014 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=August 2016}}
====Representative dismissals==== Wikimedia users organized a revolt to call for the removal of [[Arnnon Geshuri]], a member of the board of the Wikimedia Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mullin|first1=Joe|title=Wikipedia editors revolt, vote "no confidence" in newest board member|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2016/01/editors-demand-ouster-of-wikimedia-board-member-involved-in-no-poach-deal/|website=[[Ars Technica]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|accessdate=27 January 2016|date=25 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=BBC staff|title=Wikipedia editors sign vote of no confidence|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-35411208|website=[[BBC]]|accessdate=27 January 2016|date=26 January 2016}}</ref>
Wikimedia Foundation head [[Lila Tretikov]] resigned in February 2016 during a user revolt calling for institutional changes.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Motherboard team|title=Wikimedia Foundation Executive Director Resigns Amid a Community Revolt|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/wikimedia-foundation-executive-director-lila-tretikov-resigns|accessdate=27 February 2016|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|date=25 February 2016}}</ref>
===Digg===
====Publishing of DVD unlock code====
In 2007 in the [[AACS encryption key controversy]] various Internet users began publishing the decryption code for the [[Advanced Access Content System]] on various websites. The impact was that the code enabled anyone to write simple software, for example [[DeCSS]], which enabled anyone else to [[Ripping|rip DVDs]] and copy the content as they liked. The release of the key and derivative ripping programs made the illicit distribution of copyrighted media much easier for anyone who wished to share content which was formerly locked by the AACS system.
The AACS codes were published in many places. One place in which they were published was the website [[Digg]].<ref name="Nizza 2007">{{cite web |url= http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/05/02/the-day-the-digg-users-revolted/?_r=0 |title=The Day Digg Users Revolted |first=Mike |last=Nizza |work=thelede.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2 May 2007 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/03/technology/03code.html?hp |title=In Web Uproar, Antipiracy Code Spreads Wildly |first=Brad |last=Stone |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=3 May 2007 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://boingboing.net/2007/05/02/digg-users-revolt-ov.html |title=Digg users revolt over AACS key |first=Cory |last=Doctorow |work=boingboing.net |date=2 May 2007 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://readwrite.com/2007/05/04/what_happened_a_1 |title=What Happened At Digg? - ReadWrite |first=Jitendra |last=Gupta |work=readwrite.com |date=4 May 2007 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/2007/05/02/digital-rights-management-tech-cx_ag_0502digg.html |title=Digg's DRM Revolt |first=Andy |last=Greenberg |work=forbes.com |date=2 May 2007 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2007/05/aacs-la-internet-revolt-be-damned-this-fight-is-not-over/ |title=AACS LA: Internet "revolt" be damned, this fight is not over |first=Ken |last=Fisher |work=arstechnica.com |date=4 May 2007 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref>
On May 1, 2007, an article appeared on Digg's homepage that contained the [[encryption key]] for the [[Advanced Access Content System|AACS]] [[digital rights management]] protection of [[HD DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc]]. Then Digg, "acting on the advice of its lawyers," removed posting submissions about the secret number from its database and banned several users for submitting it. The removals were seen by many Digg users as a capitulation to [[corporatocracy|corporate interests]] and an assault on free speech.<ref>{{cite news | last = Stone | first = Brad | title = In Web Uproar, Antipiracy Code Spreads Wildly | pages = | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 2007-05-03 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/03/technology/03code.html | accessdate = 2007-07-02 }}</ref> A statement by [[Jay Adelson]] attributed the article's take-down to an attempt to comply with [[cease and desist]] letters from the [[Advanced Access Content System]] consortium and cited Digg's [[Terms of Use]] as justification for taking down the article.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.digg.com/?p=73|title=Digg the Blog: What's Happening with HD-DVD Stories?|first=Jay|last=Adelson}}</ref> Although some users defended Digg's actions,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tgdaily.com/content/view/31859/97/ |title=Cease and desist letters backfire horribly against AACS |publisher=TGdaily |date=2007-05-01 |accessdate=2009-02-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070504015619/http://www.tgdaily.com/content/view/31859/97/ |archive-date=2007-05-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/railsback/archives/2007/05/digg_losing_con.html |title=Digg losing control of their site |publisher=Weblog.infoworld.com |date= |accessdate=2009-02-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222071122/http://weblog.infoworld.com/railsback/archives/2007/05/digg_losing_con.html |archivedate=2008-12-22 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sanders |first=Tom |url=http://www.computing.co.uk/vnunet/news/2188970/drm-lobby-tries-hd-dvd-genie |title=DRM lobby tries to get HD DVD genie back into the bottle |publisher=Computing.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> as a whole the community staged a widespread revolt with numerous articles and comments being made using the encryption key.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytech.com/article.aspx?newsid=7129|title=DailyTech: AACS Key Censorship Leads to First Internet Riot|first=Marcus|last=Yam|accessdate=2007-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/6615047.stm|title=BBC News: DVD DRM row sparks user rebellion|accessdate=2007-05-02 | date=2007-05-02}}</ref> The scope of the user response was so great that one of the Digg users referred to it as a "digital [[Boston Tea Party]]".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070504173353/http://www.forbes.com/technology/2007/05/02/digital-rights-management-tech-cx_ag_0502digg.html Forbes.com], Digg's DRM Revolt</ref> The response was also directly responsible for Digg reversing the policy and stating: "But now, after seeing hundreds of stories and reading thousands of comments, you've made it clear. You'd rather see Digg go down fighting than bow down to a bigger company. We hear you, and effective immediately we won't delete stories or comments containing the code and will deal with whatever the consequences might be."<ref>{{cite web| url =http://blog.digg.com/?p=74 | title =Digg This: 09 F9 <nowiki>[...]</nowiki> | accessdate =2007-05-02 | first =Kevin | last = Rose | authorlink =Kevin Rose | date =2007-05-01 | work =Digg the Blog | publisher =Digg Inc }}</ref>
====Digg v4 revolt and migration to Reddit==== When [[Digg]] redesigned their website in 2010 the community revolted and used the platform to advertise a user migration to the competitor, [[reddit]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mashable.com/2010/08/30/users-revolt-against-new-digg/#6EazsZdx.aqO |title=Users Revolt Against New Digg |first=Vadim |last=Lavrusik |work=mashable.com |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://mashable.com/2011/01/03/reddit-2010-growth/#fdhicYEKeuqr |title=Reddit Grew 230% in 2010 at Digg's Expense |first=Ben |last=Parr |work=mashable.com |date=3 January 2011 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://readwrite.com/2010/08/30/digg_user_rebellion_reddit_on_front_page |title=Digg User Rebellion Continues: Reddit Now Rules the Front Page - ReadWrite |first=Frederic |last=Lardinois |work=readwrite.com |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2012/07/23/with-digg-on-the-wane-where-are-its-former-power-users |title=With Digg on the Wane, Where Are its Former Power Users? |first=Simons |last=Owens |work=usnews.com |date=23 July 2012 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2012/07/13/facebook-didnt-kill-digg-reddit-did/ |title=Facebook Didn't Kill Digg, Reddit Did |first=Paul |last=Tassi |work=forbes.com |date=13 July 2012 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/technology/pda/2010/aug/31/digg-redesign-revolt |title=Digg users revolt after redesign |first=Josh |last=Halliday |work=theguardian.com |date=31 August 2010 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/08/reddit-digg.html |title=Reddit considers itself a benefactor of Digg user revolt |first=Mark |last=Milian |work=latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=31 August 2010 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref>
Digg's version 4 release was initially unstable. The site was unreachable or unstable for weeks after its launch on August 25, 2010. Many users, upon finally reaching the site, complained about the new design and the removal of many features (such as bury, favorites, friends submissions, upcoming pages, subcategories, videos and history search).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gigaom.com/2010/08/26/digg-redesign-met-with-a-thumbs-down/ |title=Digg Redesign Met with a Thumbs Down |first1=Mathew, |last1=Ingram |date=August 26, 2010 |accessdate=August 29, 2010}}</ref> Kevin Rose replied to complaints on his blog, promising to fix the algorithm and restore some features.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kevinrose.com/blogg/2010/8/27/digg-v4-release-iterate-repeat.html |title=Digg v4: release, iterate, repeat. |first1=Kevin |last1=Rose |date=August 27, 2010 |accessdate=August 27, 2010}}</ref>
[[Alexis Ohanian]], founder of rival site [[Reddit]], said in an open letter to Rose:
{{quote|… this new version of digg reeks of [[venture capitalist|VC]] meddling. It's cobbling together features from more popular sites and departing from the core of digg, which was to "give the power back to the people."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://alexisohanian.com/an-open-letter-to-kevin-rose |title=An open letter to Kevin Rose |first1=Alexis |last1=Ohanian |date=May 28, 2010 |accessdate=August 29, 2010}}</ref>}}
Disgruntled users declared a "quit Digg day" on August 30, 2010, and used Digg's own auto-submit feature to fill the front page with content from Reddit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/digg_user_rebellion_reddit_on_front_page.php |title=Digg User Rebellion Continues: Reddit Now Rules the Front Page |publisher=ReadWriteWeb |first1=Frederic |last1=Lardinois |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831122556/http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/digg_user_rebellion_reddit_on_front_page.php |archive-date=August 31, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2010/08/30/digg-users-lash-out-at-new-format-join-forces-with-reddit/ |title=Digg Users Lash Out At New Format, Join Forces with Reddit |publisher=Time Magazine |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |date=August 30, 2010 |first1=Megan |last1=Friedman}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-20015042-36.html?part=rss&subj=news&tag=2547-1_3-0-20 |title=Angry Digg users flood home page with Reddit links |publisher=CNet News |first1=Caroline |last1=McCarthy |accessdate=August 31, 2010}}</ref> Reddit also temporarily added the Digg shovel to their logo to welcome fleeing Digg users.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/30/reddit-digg-rivalry-heats_n_699225.html |title=Angry Users SLAM Digg With Links From Rival Reddit |publisher=The Huffington Post |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |first=Craig |last=Kanalley |date=August 30, 2010}}</ref>
Digg's traffic dropped significantly after the launch of version 4,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thenextweb.com/socialmedia/2010/09/23/diggs-traffic-is-collapsing-at-home-and-abroad/ |title= Digg’s traffic is collapsing at home and abroad |publisher=The Next Web |accessdate=October 20, 2010 |first1=Alex |last1=Wilhelm}}</ref> and publishers reported a drop in direct referrals from stories on Digg's front page.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://socialkeith.com/the-digg-effect-v4/ |title=The Digg Effect v4 |publisher=Social Keith |accessdate=October 20, 2010 |first1=Keith |last1=Plocek}}</ref> New CEO Matt Williams attempted to address some of the users' concerns in a blog post on October 12, 2010, promising to reinstate many of the features that had been removed.
===Reddit=== {{see also|Reddit#IAmA and AMA}}
On July 2, 2015, Reddit began experiencing a series of blackouts as [[Internet forum#Moderators|moderators]] set popular subreddit communities to private, in an event dubbed "AMAgeddon" – a [[portmanteau]] of AMA ("ask me anything") and [[Armageddon]]. This was done in protest of the recent firing of Victoria Taylor, an administrator who helped organize citizen-led interviews with famous people on the popular "Ask me Anything" subreddit. Organizers of the blackout also expressed resentment about the recent severance of the communication between Reddit and the moderators of subreddits.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-33379571 |title=Reddit in uproar after staff sacking |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=3 July 2015 |website=BBC News |publisher=BBC |access-date=3 July 2015 |quote="About 100 chat sections, or sub-reddits, that together have millions of readers are believed to have been shut. Reddit's only comment about the issue has been to say that it did not talk about 'individual employee matters'. The protests were led by the volunteer moderators of the AMA section, which said in an explanatory posting that they needed Ms Taylor to keep the sub-reddit functioning. Ms Taylor helped organise guests for AMAs and worked to verify that people due to answer questions were who they said they were. There had been no explanation of why she was suddenly sacked, said the administrators."}}</ref> The blackout intensified on July 3 when former [[Online community manager|community manager]] David Croach gave an AMA about being fired. Before deleting his posts, he stated that [[Ellen Pao]] dismissed him with one year of health coverage when he had cancer and did not recover quickly enough.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reddit: Laute Rufe nach Absetzung von CEO Ellen Pao|url=http://derstandard.at/2000018574154/Reddit-Laute-Rufe-nach-Absetzung-von-CEO-Ellen-Pao|accessdate=5 July 2015|date=4 July 2015|quote=Zwar sind einige Foren wieder entsperrt, trotzdem ist Pao weiterhin Ziel vielerlei Angriffe. Zusätzliches Öl ins Feuer goss ein ehemaliger Community Manager der Online-Community, der angab von der Reddit-Chefin aufgrund seiner Krebserkrankung gefeuert worden zu sein. Zuvor wurde dem an Leukämie erkrankten Mitarbeiter eingeräumt, beim Unternehmen zu verbleiben – allerdings meldete sich Pao nur wenig später und gab ihm zu wissen, dass er aufgrund seiner Erkrankung nicht mehr bei Reddit verbleiben könnte. So zumindest die Behauptung, die wenig später offline ging.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Reddit's CEO Allegedly Fired an Employee For Having Cancer and Not Recovering Fast Enough|url=http://nextshark.com/ellen-pao-reddit-dacvak-ama/|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> Following this, a [[Change.org]] [[petition]] to remove Pao as CEO of Reddit Inc. reached over 200,000 signatures.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-leadership/wp/2015/07/06/nearly-200k-people-have-signed-a-petition-calling-for-reddits-ellen-pao-to-step-down/|title=More than 200k people have signed a petition calling for Reddit's Ellen Pao to step down|date=6 July 2015|accessdate=7 July 2015|publisher=The Washington Post|first=Jena|last=McGregor}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Musil|first1=Steven|title=Petition for Pao resignation from Reddit grows to 130K|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/petition-for-pao-resignation-from-reddit-grows-to-130k/|publisher=Cnet|accessdate=5 July 2015|date=5 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Malik|first1=Naureen|last2=Jones|first2=Tim|title=Reddit CEO Pao Under Fire as Users Protest Removal of Executive|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-04/reddit-restores-most-of-site-after-moderator-led-blackouts|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=5 July 2015|date=5 July 2015}}</ref> Pao posted a response on July 3 as well as an extended version of it on July 6 in which she apologized for bad communication and not delivering on promises. She also apologized on behalf of the other administrators and noted that problems already existed over the past several years.<ref>[http://money.cnn.com/2015/07/06/technology/reddit-back-online-ellen-pao/index.html Reddit CEO Ellen Pao apologizes: 'We screwed up'] By [[Laurie Segall]] and Chris Isidore ''CNN.com'' July 6, 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/07/06/reddit-ceo-ellen-pao-issues-apology-for-direction-site/ Reddit CEO Ellen Pao Issues an Apology for the Direction of the Site] by Laura Entis ''FoxNews.com'' July 06, 2015</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3946934/reddit-ellen-pao-apology-petition/|title=Ellen Pao: Reddit CEO Apologizes After Petition for Her to Resign|author=Jack Linshi|work=TIME.com|date=July 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Titcomb|first1=James|title=Petition calling for Reddit boss Ellen Pao to resign hits 200,000 as she admits 'we screwed up'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/social-media/11722560/Petition-calling-for-Reddit-boss-Ellen-Pao-to-resign-hits-200000-target-as-she-admits-we-screwed-up.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=7 July 2015|date=7 July 2015|location=London}}</ref> On July 10, Pao resigned as CEO and was replaced by former CEO and co-founder [[Steve Huffman]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = An old team at reddit • /r/announcements|url = https://www.reddit.com/r/announcements/comments/3cucye/an_old_team_at_reddit/|website = reddit|accessdate = 2015-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mike|first1=Isaac|title=Ellen Pao Is Stepping Down as Reddit's Chief|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/11/technology/ellen-pao-reddit-chief-executive-resignation.html?_r=0|accessdate=10 July 2015|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=10 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Frier|first1=Sarah|last2=Newcomer|first2=Eric|last3=Muoio|first3=Danielle|title=Reddit Revolt Shows Site’s Users Rule No Matter Who Has CEO Role|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-07/reddit-revolt-shows-site-s-users-rule-no-matter-who-has-ceo-role|website=Bloomberg Business|accessdate=27 January 2016|date=July 7, 2015}}</ref>
===Twitter=== In 2013 [[Twitter]] users organized a revolt when Twitter took away a defensive tool that allowed people to protect themselves from other users that they chose to block.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theverge.com/2013/12/12/5205462/twitter-turns-its-block-function-into-a-mute-button |title=Twitter turns its block function into a mute button, leading to user revolt |first=Josh |last=Lowensohn |work=[[The Verge]] |date=12 December 2013|accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2014/09/04/why-twitters-users-are-in-open-revolt/ |title=Why Twitter’s users are in open revolt |first=Brian |last=Fung |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=4 September 2014 |publisher=[[Washington Post Company|WPC]] |location=[[Washington, DC|Washington DC]] |issn=0190-8286 |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/twitter-abuse-idUSL1N0JS04920131213 |title=Twitter users revolt over changes to abusive behavior policy |first=Gerry |last=Shih |work=reuters.com |date=12 December 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref> In response to the revolt Twitter restored some rights to its users.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/news/twitter-backtracks-block-feature-after-users-revolt/ |title=Twitter backtracks on block feature after users revolt |author=Reuters |work=[[CBS News]] |date=13 December 2013 |publisher=[[CBS Broadcasting|CBS]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/twitter-blocking-change-decision-reversed-trolls-bullies-529964 |title=Twitter Reinstates Blocking After User Revolt |first=David |last=Gilbert |work=ibtimes.co.uk |date=13 December 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
===Instagram===
In 2012 a change to [[Instagram]]'s terms of service triggered a user revolt.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fastcompany.com/3004241/facing-user-revolt-instagram-changes-course-tos |title=Facing User Revolt, Instagram Changes Course On TOS |first=Maccabee |last=Montandon |work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|date=21 December 2012 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/18/tech/social-media/instagram-terms-users/ |title=Instagram backtracks after user privacy revolt |first=Doug |last=Gross |work=cnn.com |date=19 December 2012 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
Even during the revolt Instagram continued to get many new users.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_22673033/instagram-100-million-members-milestone-belying-reports-user-revolt |title=Instagram hits 100 million members, belying reports of user revolt |first=Jeremy C. |last=Owens |work=mercurynews.com |date=26 February 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
===Facebook=== In 2006 there was a [[Facebook]] user revolt and staff replied to users.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://techcrunch.com/2006/09/06/facebook-users-revolt-facebook-replies/ |title=Facebook Users Revolt, Facebook Replies |first=Michael |last=Arrington |work=techcrunch.com |date=6 September 2006 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook/calm-down-breathe-we-hear-you/2208197130 |title=Calm down. Breathe. We hear you. |first=Mark |last=Zuckerberg |work=facebook.com |date=5 September 2006 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
In 2007 there was a Facebook revolt over the selling of user information to advertisers.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/the-facebook-betrayal-users-revolt-over-advertising-sell-out-400855.html |title=The Facebook betrayal - users revolt over advertising sell-out |first1=Susie |last1=Mesure |first2=Ian |last2=Griggs |work=[[The Independent]] |date=17 November 2007 |publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
In 2009 there was speculation that Facebook users would revolt over privacy settings.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/so-far-no-user-revolt-over-facebooks-new-privacy-settings-2009-12 |title=So Far, No User Revolt Over Facebook's New Privacy Settings |first=Nicholas |last=Carlson |work=businessinsider.com |date=10 December 2009|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
In 2010 roughly 34,000 users left Facebook over privacy issues as a part of the May 31 "Quit Facebook Day" campaign.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/may/23/facebook-network-begins-to-unravel |title=Facebook users revolt against Mark Zuckerberg over privacy |first=James |last=Robinson |work=theguardian.com |date=22 May 2010 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brewster|first1=Tom|title=Quit Facebook Day inspires over 30,000 to leave|url=http://www.itpro.co.uk/623839/quit-facebook-day-inspires-over-30000-to-leave|website=ITPRO|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing Limited]]|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref>
===AOL=== In 1997 [[AOL]] amended their [[Terms of service]] to permit them to sell users' telephone numbers to [[Telemarketing|telemarketers]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=KAPLAN|first1=KAREN|title=AOL Drops Plans to Sell Members' Phone Numbers|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/jul/25/news/mn-16206|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=25 July 1997}}</ref> Users complained and in response AOL offered an [[opt-out]] system.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bray|first1=Hiawatha|title=AOL's subscribers to get new `service': telemarketing calls|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/573945/AOLs-subscribers-to-get-new-service-telemarketing-calls.html|accessdate=24 December 2016|work=DeseretNews.com|date=24 July 1997}}</ref><ref name="Wu 2016">{{cite book|last1=Wu|first1=Tim|authorlink1=Tim Wu|title=The Attention Merchants: The Epic Scramble to Get Inside Our Heads|date=2016|publisher=[[Penguin Random House]]|location=New York|isbn=9780385352017|page=211|quote=an inadvertent leak of the plan prompted a user revolt and the telemarketing part was abandoned }}</ref>
===The Pirate Bay=== In 2009 [[Global Gaming Factory X]] sought to purchase [[The Pirate Bay]].<ref name="Greenberg 2009">{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/2009/06/30/pirate-bay-revolt-technology-internet-users.html |title=The Pirate Bay's Revolt |first=Andy |last=Greenberg |work=forbes.com |date=30 June 2009|accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> This led to a user revolt when community participants protested that the sale was a betrayal of community values.<ref name="Greenberg 2009"/>
===Livejournal=== [[Livejournal]] users revolted in 2007 when Livejournal deleted some site content.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cnet.com/news/mass-deletion-sparks-livejournal-revolt/ |title=Mass deletion sparks LiveJournal revolt |first=Declan |last=McCullagh |work=cnet.com |date=31 May 2007 |accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox pageant titleholder | name=Varinthorn Phadoongvithee | title=[[Miss Thailand Universe|Miss Thailand Universe 2001]] | nationalcompetition=[[Miss Thailand Universe|Miss Thailand Universe 2001]] (winner), [[Miss Thailand|Miss Thailand 1998]], [[Miss Universe 2001]] | birth_place= [[Nonthaburi Province|Nonthaburi]], [[Thailand]] | birth_name= Varinthorn Phadoongvithee | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1976|10|28}} | nickname= Auan | height={{height|ft=5|in=8}} | eye_color= Black | hair_color= Black | measurements = 32-25-36 | ethnicity= [[Asian people|Asian]] }} '''Varinthorn Phadoongvithee''' ({{lang-th|วรินทร ผดุงวิถี}}) is a businesswoman and the 2001 [[Miss Thailand Universe]].
==Biography== Varinthorn Phadoongvithee was born and raised in Nonthaburi.
==Pageantry== Phadoongvithee was crowned second Miss Thailand Universe on March 24, 2001.
After becoming Miss Thailand Universe, she travelled to [[Bayamón]], [[Puerto Rico]] to compete in the [[Miss Universe 2001]] pageant, held at the [[Coliseo Rubén Rodríguez]] on May 11, 2001 but did not place. Miss Puerto Rico, [[Denise Quiñones]] was crowned Miss Universe 2001.
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6rwgBFdHayw Crowning Moment] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071019112334/http://www.mardoo.net/ Sawasdee Pageant The Majestic World of Beauty Pageant]
{{S-start}} {{Succession box | before=[[Kulthida Yenprasert]] | title=[[Miss Thailand Universe]] | years=2001 | after=[[Janjira Janchome]] }} {{S-end}} {{Miss Universe 2001 delegates}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Padungvithee, Warinthorn}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Miss Universe 2001 contestants]] [[Category:Miss Universe Thailand winners]] [[Category:People from Nonthaburi Province]] [[Category:Thai businesspeople]]

{{infobox company |name = Zi Corporation |former_name = Multi-Corp Inc |logo = Zi Corporation.jpg |logo_size = 110px |type = [[Privately held company|Private]] |traded_as = {{ublist|{{NASDAQ was|ZICA}}|{{TSX was|ZIC}}}} |industry = [[Software]] |founded = {{start date|1987}} in [[Calgary]], Canada<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Zi Corporation|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=235233|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> |fate = Aqcuired by [[Nuance Communications]] |defunct = {{end date|2009|04|09}} |key_people = {{ublist|Milos Djokovic (President and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])|Blair Mullin ([[Chief financial officer|CFO]]|George Tai ([[Chairman]])}} |areas_served = {{ublist|Canada|China|Sweden|United States}} |products = {{ublist|Decuma|eZiText|eZiType|Qix}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Zi - Corporation review|url=http://www.techvibes.com/company-directory/zi-corporation|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> |revenue = {{CAD|13323492}} |revenue_year = 2008 |assets = {{CAD|8327550}} |assets_year = 2008 |num_employees = 77 |num_employees_year = 1987 |homepage = <u>zicorp.com</u> (defunct)<!--{{URL|zicorp.com}} now defunct, with link to possible phising site--> |hq_location_city = [[Calgary]] |hq_location_country = Canada }} '''Zi Corporation''' was a [[software]] company based in [[Calgary]], Canada. The company was founded on 4 December 1987 as Cancom Ventures Inc, owning an [[Edmonton]] secretarial college and an industrial equipment rental business. On 30 August 1989 the name was changed to Multi-Corp Inc. In 1993, board member Michael Lobsinger took control of the company, became CEO, and turned the company towards the [[telecommunications]] industry, purchasing several privately held companies involved in the telecommunications businesses,<ref name=China>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianbusiness.com/business-strategy/china-calling/|title=China calling|publisher=[[Canadian Business]]|date=22 November 2004|last1=Wahl|first1=Andrew|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref> and in November 1993, Multi-Corp entered into an exclusive licensing agreement with Eric Chappell for a stroke-based [[Chinese language|Chinese]] text entry system which they referred to as the ''Jiejing Licenses''.<ref name=Geist>{{cite book|last1=Geist|first1=Richard|title=Investor Therapy: A Psychologist and Investing Guru Tells You How to Out-Psych Wall Street|date=23 Sep 2003|publisher=Crown Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-60960-916-3}}</ref> A wholly owned subsidiary, Ziran Developments Inc, was formed to handle the Chinese text entry business. The company was listed on the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]] on 9 June 1995 (symbol MCU).<ref name=Klein /> Under Lobsinger, the strategic importance of the Chinese text entry grew, and Ziran was renamed Zi Corporation in 1996; ''Zi'' meaning ''character'' in Chinese. The telecommunications businesses were disposed of by 1997<ref>[http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/DisplayFiling.aspx?TabIndex=2&FilingID=5832654&companyid=97501&ppu=%252fdefault.aspx%253fcompanyid%253d97501%2526amp%253bformtypeId%253d53 Zi Corp entry], Edgar Online.</ref> In June 1997, the parent company was renamed Zi Corporation to reflect the importance of the new business. In 1999, co-founder [[Gary Kovacs]] joined as COO.<!-- left in 2003 for Macromedia -->
Having started with Chinese on [[personal computer]]s, toward the end of the 1990s Zi's focus moved to text entry for all languages for [[mobile phone]]s and other handheld devices, where efficient entry of text traditionally has been challenging due to limitations of a physically small device.<ref name=China /> This new business area was quickly quite successful, especially in the Chinese market, and in 1998 Zi entered into licensing agreements with Ericsson (later [[Sony Ericsson]]), who at that time was a very significant player in the Chinese market.<ref name=China /><ref name="1998 Annual Report">{{cite web|title=Zi Corporation 1998 Annual Report|url=http://globaldocuments.morningstar.com/documentlibrary/document/3405d5ef283dbaf1.msdoc/original|website=[[Morningstar, Inc.|Morningstar]]|publisher=Zi Corporation|accessdate=27 December 2015|format=PDF}}</ref> Further license agreements with Ericsson and other companies were to follow, for a total of more than 1000 different device models being shipped with Zi text entry software,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Au|first1=Maggie|title=Sony Ericsson signs expansion deal with Zi Corp.|journal=[[Telecom Asia]]|date=16 September 2008|url=http://www.telecomasia.net/content/sony-ericsson-signs-expansion-deal-zi-corp-0|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref> in more than 100 million devices.<ref name=VisionMobile>{{cite web|last1=Constantinou|first1=Andreas|title=Watchlist: The 100 million club|url=http://www.visionmobile.com/blog/2008/04/watchlist-the-100-million-club/|publisher=[[VisionMobile]]|date=2008|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
The introduction of [[touch screen]] technology for mobile devices made the company follow up with software for handwriting recognition, with focus on languages such as Chinese and [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. In 2003, Mike Donnell took over as CEO from Lobsinger.<ref name=China /> Zi Corporation was listed on [[NASDAQ]] from September 2007 .<ref>[http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/zi-corporation-application-to-trade-on-the-nasdaq-capital-market-approved-nasdaq-zica-766930.htm Zi Corporation Application to Trade on the NASDAQ Capital Market Approved]</ref>
Text entry on devices with limited number of keys was early subject to a number of [[software patent]]s, and Zi was engaged in several costly patent disputes with [[Tegic Corporation]], later [[Nuance Communications]]. In August 2008, Nuance made a takeover bid to acquire the company for {{USD|40.4}} million, which the company declined. Shortly thereafter, Nuance filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Zi.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kapko|first1=Matt|title=Nuance Sues Zi Corp. For Patent Infringement Days After It Rejects Takeover Offer|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/25/AR2008082502093.html|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|date=25 August 2008}}</ref><ref name=xconomy>{{cite web|url=http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2008/08/18/canadas-zi-corporation-hopes-to-fend-off-nuance-takeover-companies-issue-dueling-statements/ |title=Canada’s Zi Corporation Hopes to Fend Off Nuance Takeover; Companies Issue Dueling Statements|publisher=[[Xconomy]]|accessdate=25 Dec 2015}}</ref> The company was finally acquired by Nuance for {{USD|35}} million on 26 February 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2009/02/nuance-buys-zi-corp-for-35m.html|title=Nuance buys Zi Corp. for $35M|publisher=[[Boston Business Journal]]|date=27 February 2009|accessdate=25 Dec 2015}}</ref> and the acquisition was completed on 9 April 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nuance.com/news/pressreleases/2009/20090409_ziClosing.asp |title=Nuance Closes Acquisition of Zi Corporation|publisher=Nuance Communications|date=27 February 2009|accessdate=29 Dec 2015}}</ref>
==Products== Zi's main product was ''EZiText'' [[predictive text entry]] software, in competition with solutions such as the original [[T9 (predictive text)|T9]] product from Tegic, later Nuance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2006/06/16/zi-announces-advanced-chinese-text-messaging-input-system/ |title=Zi announces advanced Chinese text messaging input system]|publisher=[[Engadget]]|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> Other products include ''eZiType'', a predictive text entry product for mobile email users, for keyboard-based mobile devices, ''Qix'', a service discovery engine that provides a quick and easy method for accessing a phone's features, applications, and services, and ''Decuma'' which delivers an input method for pen-based devices by fusing handwriting recognition with predictive text technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zi Corporation Completes Acquisition of Assets of Decuma AB of Sweden|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050126005704/en/Zi-Corporation-Completes-Acquisition-Assets-Decuma-AB|accessdate=29 December 2015|date=26 January 2005}}</ref>
==Patent war== There was a series of [[patent infringement]] lawsuits between Tegic, the holder of the T9 patents, and Zi: * A patent infringement lawsuit by Zi against Tegic, filed in the District Court in Seattle for Japanese and Chinese character-based text input technologies was dismissed in September 1999.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tegic Wins Patent Infringement Dispute; U.S. District Court In Seattle Summarily Dismisses Zi Corp Claims.|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Tegic+Wins+Patent+Infringement+Dispute%3B+U.S.+District+Court+In...-a055731624|accessdate=29 December 2015|date=13 September 1999}}</ref> * In February 2002, the District Court for Northern California granted Zi a partial summary judgment that eZiText for alphabetic does not infringe on Tegic's patents.<ref>{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}</ref> * In March 2002, the Federal District Court for the Western District of Washington granted Zi partial summary judgment stating that eZiText for alphabetic languages does not infringe Tegic's text input patents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Zi+Claims+Second+Patent+Victory+Against+Tegic+Communications,+a+Unit...-a083757620|title=Zi Claims Second Patent Victory Against Tegic Communications, a Unit of AOL Time Warner.|date=14 March 2002|accessdate=29 December 2015}}</ref> * In September 2002, the U.S. District Court for Northern California awarded Tegic, owned by [[AOL]] [[Time Warner]], {{USD|9}} million in damages for Zi's infringement of two Tegic patents. Zi's claim that the two Tegic patents were based on existing methods of inputting Chinese ideographic characters were rejected.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tegic Hails Sweeping Legal Victory in Patent Infringement Lawsuit Against Zi Corporation|url=http://www.timewarner.com/newsroom/press-releases/2002/09/05/tegic-hails-sweeping-legal-victory-in-patent-infringement-lawsuit|accessdate=29 December 2015|publisher=[[Time Warner]]|date=5 September 2002}}</ref> * In August 2008 Nuance filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Zi in the Federal Court in Toronto, Canada, where Nuance accuses Zi of infringing Canadian Patent Numbers 2,399,961 and 2,278,549, each entitled "Reduced Keyboard Disambiguating System.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nuance and Its Subsidiary Tegic Communications File Patent Infringement Lawsuit Against Zi Corporation|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS143090+25-Aug-2008+BW20080825|accessdate=29 December 2015|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=25 August 2008}}</ref>
== Other controversies == * In 1995 the company sold stock to the wives of [[Alberta]] Premier [[Ralph Klein]] and his chief of staff [[Rod Love]] well below market value, with no payment required until they sold them. Klein had participated in a ribbon-cutting ceremony at the company’s Hong Kong office while Love served as a company director. Klein was later cleared of wrongdoing in a decision by Alberta's Ethics Commissioner [[Robert Curtis Clark|Bob Clark]],<ref name=China /><ref name=Klein>{{cite web|title=Investigation Report: November 10, 1995 1 REPORT OF INVESTIGATION INTO ALLEGATIONS RELATING TO THE HON. RALPH KLEIN, PREMIER|url=http://www.ethicscommissioner.ab.ca/media/1057/multicorp95.pdf|publisher=Alberta Ethics Commissioner|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=Post>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianhedgewatch.com/content/news/general/?id=205 |title=Calgary firm linked to hedge fund investigation|website=Canadian Hedgewatch|publisher=[[National Post]]|date=12 August 2003|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> although this decision was controversial.<ref name=Teflon>{{cite web|url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/alberta/ralph+klein+teflon+premier+nine+lives/8171734/story.html||last1=Henton|first1=Darcy|title=Ralph Klein—the Teflon premier—and his nine lives|publisher=[[Calgary Herald]]|date=28 March 2013|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=Western>{{cite news|last1=Mrozek|first1=Andrea|title=The Right Connections|url=http://investorvoice.ca/PI/2439.htm|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=[[Western Standard]]|date=12 December 2005}}</ref> * In 1998, Eric Chappell receives 4.5 million shares as compensation for transfer of all rights of the ''Jiejing Licenses'' to Zi. 3 million shares, representing 11.5% of the shares, are sold to Lancer Funds without disclosure, as is required by law.<ref name=Western /> * In 2003, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] froze the assets of Lancer Group, a [[hedge fund]] investment management firm, when it discovered it owned 49.1% of Zi's shares, far beyond the 10% limit requiring disclosure. This was suspected to be for market manipulation, and the Lancer assets were taken over by an appointed receiver.<ref name=China /><ref name=Post /> Zi entered into a settlement agreement with the SEC.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zi Corporation and Marty Steinberg, Receiver for the Lancer Funds, Enter into Settlement Agreement|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/922658/000120445907000264/zic0223exh991.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref>
